And so it should have been: a 16-year-old entering the work force is not going to be very productive. In my first year, I swept the floor about three times a day and went and got the lunches and did that sort of thing, and I was not very productive at all. Some would say that I am not very productive now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes; they would!

—I thank the member for Moreton, but that is not the case. The benefits come to the employer from an apprenticeship in the second half of the indentured period, not in the first half. In fact, I can say from personal experience that the second half of an apprenticeship period for an employee is very productive. The salary levels, when I started, were reflected in that pay scale. However, it did change rapidly, once that initial, non-productive period was over. So 20 per cent of the adult journeyman wage was what I was receiving.

PARA.TAB: In most cases, it seems that the first-year apprentice salary now is more like 40 per cent of the adult wage. I am not advocating any change of policy on wages for apprentices, other than to point out that, since apprenticeship salaries have been brought into line with adult salaries, the number of apprenticeships has fallen. One does not have to be a Rhodes scholar to realise the relationship between salary and opportunity. If an employer wanted to employ someone, who would he employ? Would he employ, for instance, a skilled worker on an adult wage, or would he employ an apprentice, who is unproductive for many years, on 40 per cent of the adult wage? Speaking from personal experience, I do not blame small businesses for employing a skilled worker. In today's environment, employers need to be more attuned to the operational costs of the enterprise rather than being philanthropic with the training up of young people. Therefore, they are seeking the best value for their enterprise dollar, and are making it a well-spent dollar.

Where today is the incentive for employers to provide a future for our country by providing opportunities and training for our youth? We hear a lot about wage incentives and all sorts of programs, but the fact is that there is not a lot of opportunity for young people these days in training programs of any significance. That is why, I guess, the unions are lamenting the fact that we are importing skilled labour. If they are lamenting this, they should in fact look to their own policies and allow incentives which encourage employers to encourage and employ our young. This notion is often pooh-poohed by those in the so-called know of policy development and that sort of thing but, in the real world, employers do need incentives to employ our young people. Currently, when we have an unemployment figure of greater than 30 per cent, it is a serious issue: we should never accept those sorts of figures, but we are doing so at the moment.

The amendments to the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill 1995 cover some administration requirements to operate the act, yet they are beginning to be even more bureaucratic and regressive. Frankly, the act is a bit cumbersome. Amendments which make it harder for young people who need encouragement and hope are not the activities of a government which cares about our youth. The government brags about keeping kids at school until year 12, saying that it is a step closer to making us the clever country. But is it really clever to keep at school until year 12 those children who do not want to be there?

Keeping a youth at school when there is no hope of moving on to university certainly should be questioned. What are the benefits for that particular youth, now and in the future, and what are the benefits for the community? When one observes the curriculum that a lot of these year 12 students are studying at the moment, one has to question the significance of staying on. Are we, in fact, making these youths job ready whilst they are at school? The answer to that question is a definite no. This is not the fault of the students, nor of the schools, nor of the curriculum. It is my view that it is the fault of the economy, which does not allow young people to enter the work force at a young age into a career that can help them develop work skills.

Frankly, the Labor government is to blame for this sorry situation. Without moving into an economic debate concerning these amendments, I would just like to say that the prolonged poor industrial policy, which has seen an increase in the numbers of long-term unemployed, a drop in the availability of apprenticeships and a huge youth unemployment factor, has been detrimental to the development of our young people in Australia. As I said before, young people are our greatest asset.

As an example of how the government has changed the thinking and market for youth employment, I would like to relate an experience I had with a human resource manager from a leading Australian company in Perth. This HR manager said that he employed only year 12 students. I asked him why he did not employ 16-year-olds that leave school at year 10. He said that year 12 students are more intelligent. I thought about that for a while. How can year 12 students be more intelligent? It is only a difference of two years. He said that because they stay on at school they are more intelligent. I said that that would put out the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who left school at 15. He said, `Well, we believe that year 12 students are more intelligent.'

I asked him what the turnover rate was among people who came to work for him. He said, `It is huge; 18- to 20-year-olds don't stick around.' I asked him what he had them doing, and he answered that they were doing filing and basic things in training. I said, `Would it not be a better investment for you to have a four-year training program for 16- to 20-year-olds so that you can train them up? They might not be productive in the first couple of years but you would have a good asset in an employee later on who has been four-year trained and loyal.' He did not quite see the point in doing that. He would rather have year 12 students.

The requirement to have year 12 is creating greater demand within our employment sector. Young people who probably cannot cope with the school system—like, for instance, our Prime Minister—have not got an opportunity of moving into the employment market these days. The great concern I have is that we are not providing opportunities for those who do not meet the required qualifications.

I would also highlight my concerns about the future for our country, which according to current figures will have a shortage of skilled labour moving into the 21st century. We are creating a group of people who will not be allowed to enter the workplace in the future because we are not providing the opportunities for them now. Yes, we are providing welfare and training allowances and all that, but it does not seem to be working—there is a 30 per cent unemployment rate at the moment. What we really need in Australia is skilled workers, and we are not providing the training to develop those skilled workers.

Let us look, for example, at the current rate of student enrolment at our universities. The government quite rightly says that there are more people at university now than there ever have been before. That is a fact. There are more people at university now than there ever have been before.

TALK.START.PARA: —More people in Australia, too.

—Yes. But the fact of the matter is that there are actually fewer new students entering university right now. How can that be? We have got more students at university but there are actually fewer getting the opportunity to move into university. There are more people staying on at university now, however, doing double degrees. Why they are staying on is that jobs just are not available. I heard recently the Vice-Chancellor of the ANU saying that, because there are so many people studying law now in Australia that there are more people studying law than are actually practising, a law degree is virtually an arts degree now.

PARA.TAB: We are facing a real challenge in Australia at the moment regarding training our young people. We have to question whether we should be just keeping them as academics—keeping them at school longer and even at university. We have got to get them into the work force and skill up our work force, or in the future when our population drifts off we will not have that skilled labour available.

Why do we need these amendments? It seems that most of them are uncontroversial, although the shadow minister did signal that some challenges to them will take place in the Senate. However, there are a few points I would like to make under schedule 13. Paraphrased, it says basically that the secretary can determine whether a young person has failed to enter into a youth training agreement if the person fails to attend the negotiation of the agreement, fails to respond to correspondence about the agreement or fails to agree to terms of the agreement proposed by the CES, or otherwise it is considered that the person is unreasonably delaying entering into the agreement. If the terms are not met, then the youth will have the entitlement revoked. In other words, people who do not meet the terms agreed by the CES will lose their benefits.

I have an example which came to me recently.A young man who I think is about 17 has been out of school and unemployed for two years. He suffers with a bit of dyslexia; that is probably the reason why he left school. He was told by the people running a training program:

SPEECH.PARA: As you are no doubt aware, failure to attend the start of a program will result in your benefits being withdrawn.
That is a clear case of `Either you do this or your benefits are going to go.'

PARA.TAB: What was the program that he was asked to do? I will read this out. The Royal Life Saving Society was running an aquatic care program, and advertising it as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Royal Lifesaving Society is desperate to find young people to spend six months of fun in the sun. If you enjoy swimming, surfing, abseiling and the great outdoors, we are the people to see. Come and join our aquatic care program.
What does the aquatic care program actually involve, other than the basic Royal Life Saving Society's certificates? It states:
The experiences and the training that you will receive during this particular program include: surfing, windsurfing, bodyboarding, canoeing, abseiling and a variety of other cultural experiences.
Cultural experiences? Let us see what the other cultural experiences are. They include: fishing, sailing, surfing, snorkelling and powerboat driving.

PARA.TAB: This course may be a very good course to build self-esteem. But the problem with that building of self-esteem is what happens at the end of the particular course, after people have had their self-esteem built up. According to the person from the department whom I spoke to recently, they lose all their long-term unemployment status and they go back to the start of the queue.

I have to question that fact about these courses. People build up their self-esteem and then, if they do not get a job in abseiling—I do not know of many jobs in abseiling or powerboat driving being advertised—they go back to the start of the queue and start the regressive demands upon their self-esteem again. Here we are, building up self-esteem, then dropping them off and starting it all over again.

Why are we doing that to our young people, who are the future of our country? It is probably not meant to be the case, but I think what is happening is that those smart politicians in the department and those smart politicians in the government are seeing this as a way of fudging the figures in relation to a true reflection of the unemployment situation in Australia.

These amendments add to the cumbersome nature of the original act. The original act does not provide jobs; it only provides a form of training allowance. The original act is difficult to administer, as the shadow minister pointed out. The original act adds to the fraud the government tries to place upon the Australian people by trying to hide the true unemployment position of the country. As I just explained, if you lose your long-term status you go back to the start again. When the government says that numbers of long-term unemployed are being reduced, are they being reduced by the training programs, or are they, in fact, being hidden in some way? Again, these amendments add to the cumbersome nature of the original act. They take away an appeal process for aggrieved young people and place the appeal process—creating an inordinate power base—with the minister.

The real issue is the way we provide for our young. Are we to accept that government should be providing for our young, or are we to accept the fact that our community has a responsibility to look after our young people? We, as a community, should be responsible for our young people. We should be encouraging and empowering those who have the power to employ and train young people to employ young people. Yet we are bogging them down with bureaucratic amendments and acts.

Can we afford to not be concerned about our most precious asset—our young people—when so many of them are looking for some direction from the leaders of the country? They are looking to us for some leadership and some hope. I only hope that they see a future for themselves within our great country, and they move above the social welfare life that the Labor government would like to have them engulfed by.

The assets of this country are its people. Our young people play an important role in the future of our country, and we should never ignore them. I really do hope that these bureaucratic things that the government is putting in place are, in fact, trying to assist. I have given a couple of examples where that is not happening. I hope that the government takes on board the real concerns of the community. I am sure that, together, we can find some solutions. But, until we start working together as a community—certainly within the employment sector—our young people will not have the direction and hope that they long for.
I will conclude my remarks by saying that I wish the minister well within the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to participate in this debate on the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill 1995. I want, in the opening of my remarks on this very important legislation for young, unemployed people in our country, to make reference to the shadow minister who spoke earlier on this matter, and to express my concern about his various pronouncements and attacks—made not only in the debate, but also in his press releases—on our government's apparent fudging of our long-term and other employment statistics.

PARA.TAB: For instance, he is quoted in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 2 June entitled `Drop in jobless numbers found to be misleading'. I quote the journalist Mark Riley who says:

SPEECH.PARA: Figures obtained by opposition spokesperson Dr David Kemp show that more than 150,000 long-term unemployed people have been placed in work programs of 13 weeks or longer.
He suggests that what we have then done is to reclassify all these people. The article goes on to say:
About 70,000 long-term unemployed people have lost their long-term status after participating in short-term government job training schemes and returning to the dole queues.

This is the sort of thing that the shadow minister gets into time and time again, instead of getting on with some constructive policy. We never hear about policy on these matters. What we get is a continual attempt to cut and paste the figures.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) has commented in two press releases on this matter in an attempt to get the facts through. He is very kind to the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp). He says, in his press release of 2 June:

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Kemp is clearly unable to understand simply facts.

I believe the minister was being very altruistic. I would instead suggest that the shadow spokesperson actively and consistently misconstrues the facts to put a very wrong interpretation on these figures. As the minister says, referring to the Bureau of Statistics:

The ABS definition has not changed in any substantive way in at least nine years. Its definition of long-term unemployment is an internationally accepted definition. Is Dr Kemp really proposing that Australia move away from this?

It has nothing to do with CES classifications. The important issue is that long-term unemployed people who are on training programs are in no way reclassified. Those long-term unemployed people who get a guaranteed job offer—which was part of our job compact and part of Working Nation and has been most successful—may, in fact, be in employment from six to 12 months, not 13 weeks. Having had that effective work experience, they then obviously lose their long-term unemployment status. The figure that Dr Kemp has suggested in his press release is 70,000 people, but in the minister's press release of 5 June, in which he quotes Dr Kemp's release, he asks the question:
Are there 70,000 people who start their employment or training programs as long-term unemployed and are still unemployed but now classified as short-term unemployed?
And the minister says:

This is not correct. In fact, in 1994/95, less than 10,000 have been classified as short-term unemployed after they have completed or left their employment program. Many more of those people go on to full-time unsubsidised jobs.

The job compact, with case management of long-term unemployed, has been one of the real success stories of Working Nation. Why was this so? Because the government went out and engaged in a very long consultative process with community groups, with people from all sectors of business, government and service sectors in this area, listened to what the community said and then brought together in Working Nation a truly historic group of initiatives.

PARA.TAB: One of these, of course, is the youth training initiative which we are defending. I anticipate and I hope that in question time today the minister will once again nail this sort of nonsense from the shadow spokesperson who is adept at this, but I do not see that he is very adept at getting a policy position together on this or any other matter. I want to also make the point that the OECD economic survey of Australia for 1995 has praised our Working Nation initiatives, particularly the job compact. That survey says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Working Nation package will, in a relatively efficient way, help ease the difficulties the long-term unemployed have experienced in obtaining a job. These initiatives are an important element of the government's strategy to bring the unemployment rate down to five per cent over the next five years. The overall impact of the Working Nation employment package on the labour market will depend importantly on the quality of its design and implementation.

We have effectively achieved a great deal in this matter in a very short time. Not only have we delivered a huge number of jobs back into the economy; in comparison to the 1980s recovery, in particular, the long-term unemployed group in our unemployment statistics have been picked up precisely because we have put effective management of this group into the system. That is also true of our youth training initiative, which the amendments to this bill are designed to make even more effective.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Main Committee that the youth training initiative commenced in January of this year—only this year—and it aims to assist young unemployed people between 15 and 17. It may have escaped the notice of the opposition, Mr Deputy Speaker, but let me remind you that this issue of long-term unemployed youth is not new. If we care to look back at the statistics—and I certainly hope opposition members will do so—we see that young people who leave school early are very likely to be in the long-term unemployed category, because the world has moved on. Technology changes in workplaces have meant that while 10, 15 or 20 years ago kids used to leave school at 15 and get a job in a bank or a factory and work their way up, those jobs are no longer available for them.

This government realised this fact, and over the lifetime of this government we have moved to increase education for young people. During his last visit to Rockhampton, when he opened an information technology building at the Central Queensland University, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) reminded the audience that, when we came into government in 1983, three out of 10 young people completed high school. The figure now is closer to nine out of 10, in the space of 12 years. As the Prime Minister said on that occasion, we cannot make a clever country if only three out of 10 of our children finish basic high school.

Today, we would be appalled to think that would be an acceptable figure. I am sure nobody in the opposition or anywhere else in the community would consider that to be an effective number; and yet under the last government that was fine. That was okay. Then, we had people who needed to move to the top to get the university places, overwhelmingly from the middle class and the professional class. They were the people going to university. As the Prime Minister said during his Rockhampton visit, the reasons we moved to introduce HECS and a system of university students contributing to their own education was that, in spite of the groundbreaking innovation of the Whitlam government to make university studies free, nothing had in fact changed in terms of the demographics of young people going to university. Effectively, the working taxpayers—those people defined on the other side as the battlers—were still paying for the free university education of the middle classes and the professional classes.

There was no equity or justice or access in that, Mr Deputy Speaker. That is why we brought in a contribution by all university students when they were able to afford to pay it—effectively, when they were earning average weekly earnings. Because they were most likely to be in the upper percentages of income earners after they had completed their university studies, that enabled this government to put another 30 per cent of university places in the system. That effectively benefited the battlers, the women, the people from non-English speaking backgrounds, and the sons and daughters of what we would call the ordinary salary and wage earners; so this government's record is a very proud one.

However, it is certainly true, given that we had a huge intake and a continuation of young people through high school, that we were not catering effectively for their needs. We saw that, when young people did drop out, they were very likely to be in the dole queues; not even learning to develop those job skills that would make them job-ready. A lot of concern was expressed by communities during those consultations that, when young people were able just to go and get the dole, that was a disincentive for them to get education or to participate in work and training opportunities. But if young people leave school early, they are 2 1/2 times more likely to become long-term unemployed than those who do not complete secondary school.

The member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) said that the human resources people are wrong and that there is a difference in intelligence. That is not the issue. The issue is that there are basic skills and competencies that are required across all work situations. Flexible training of young people will enable them to pick up and use that skill base in a variety of work opportunities. There are very few jobs for people without skills these days. Those days have gone. While the members of the opposition seem to think that the world has not moved on since the 1950s, we know that it has.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's unkind, very unkind.
—I know that my good comrade the honourable member for Cowper recalls the 1950s.
—Good what?

—My good comrade on the other side, the member for Cowper, remembers the 1950s very well. I myself remember the 1950s, but I do not remember them as the halcyon days when all was well and Menzies still—
—Point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—The member for Capricornia will direct her remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise, Mr Deputy Speaker. How could I forget about that after the debate in the House yesterday. To continue, irrespective of the backward looking, wistful views of the opposition, the facts are that we have to make sure that young people get an opportunity to stay in the training process well past their 18th birthday. The great demographic changes mean that all parents must realise that they will be supporting their children well past their 18th birthday. I want to reassure the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) that he is in for the long haul and that he will be poor for a long time.

PARA.TAB: The youth training allowance initiatives are very important. Every person who drops out of school is being regarded as a high-risk individual who needs special help. The youth training initiative relates income support to training and work preparation schemes to make sure that people are effectively case managed. In that way, the problems that perhaps led to their dropping out of school will not re-occur.

We realise the difficulties the school system faces in servicing an increasingly diverse group of young people across a wide educational agenda. Young people who drop out of the school system often have particular problems in terms of their ability to handle the system, family support and so on. These people need particular help.

In the last budget the government reincorporated some youth training initiatives that had previously been run through the JPET program—the job placement and employment training program—of the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe). We had a very useful pilot program in my electorate of Rockhampton. That program had previously been administered through the Department of Housing and Regional Development. In Rockhampton we had the Youthtrek program which dealt with the hard-to-reach group of young people who were unready to cope with the system administered by DEET.

There was a great deal of concern expressed—not only by service providers, but also by other people in the community, and some of it was very misinformed—that we were suddenly going to cut off this group of young people. Nothing was further from the truth. That program and the very positive initiatives that the JPET program had demonstrated in its handling of some of these very difficult-to-reach young clients have been incorporated into the youth training initiative. It provides those young people with access to a wider range of programs, without losing sight of their specific needs.

This is the track record that this government has. Not only do we go out and consult, and find out what the concerns are out in the community, and what the needs are, but we pilot models to find out what is going to be most effective to help young people. We do not just think about it and say, `Wouldn't it be nice,' and get into headland speeches full of rhetoric, but no real, concrete policies. Cape Tribulation, Mount Hopeless, what is it going to be? I refer honourable members to Nicholson's cartoon in the Australian today; it shows a wonderful lighthouse.

This government has a track record of policy formulation and policy implementation. We should also be aware that there has been a very good take up of this program. There is another headline, which also comes out of the shadow spokesperson's stable, but was filtered through the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville). On 27 April 1995, he put out a press release saying, `Youth unemployment grows,' referring to a 36.3 per cent rate. The media, as we know, take a fairly simple, straightforward view. The next step was a headline in the Rockhampton Morning Bulletin saying, `One in three unemployed.' That was a pretty big jump. It did mention youth unemployment. All of a sudden we were fighting this claim that one in three Central Queenslanders were unemployed.

The shadow spokesperson had taken some figures from DEET statistics—once again this is the cut and paste job that the shadow spokesperson is famous for—and said that there were these dreadful figures. When I spoke to my DEET office in Rockhampton, I discovered that in fact the youth unemployment rate in Central Queensland varies from month to month. While it was true that in April it was approximately 35.4 per cent, the previous April it had been 50 per cent in our region, but that had varied month by month to a low of 20 per cent in August 1994, 21 per cent in November and 26 per cent in December. When the school leavers hit the job market, looking for the right job or program, the unemployment rate rises again.

Misuse of the statistics for a cheap political point is the stock-in-trade of the opposition. That is not a substitute for any sort of effective policy. The government continues to snooker the opposition, because it has policies which are put into practice. We target resources efficiently, because we have to be responsible with the taxpayer's dollar at the end of the day.

I noticed from the headland speech last night that suddenly we have a born-again Leader of the Opposition. Suddenly the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is going to be caring and sharing. He is not going to cut government spending. He is going to keep all our policies; he has finally decided that Medicare will be there—

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of them are ours anyway. You pinched them.
—That is a matter of opinion. I would not like to have a debate with the member for Cowper on Medicare and the deplorable history of the opposition on medical schemes.

PARA.TAB: I want to support the initiatives of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free). The government will continue to meet the needs of young unemployed people. At the end of the day we need those people in our work force, contributing to our future and our economy, and to their own self-esteem. That is what the youth training initiative is all about; that is what our vision for the future is all about. Not only do we have vision; we have policies, and we have put those policies into place. We get results. That is why we will win the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill 1995. The major purpose of this bill is to ensure that legislation and government services which deal with young people have the same provisions in the areas where a common approach is needed. To that end, the bill we have before us today seeks to amend the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 so that it complements the changes which are being made, and have been made, to the Social Security Act 1991.

PARA.TAB: In January this year, the youth training initiative became part of the federal Labor government's very successful Working Nation program. This initiative is substantial. It has given young unemployed Australians under the age of 18 access to one-on-one case management, income support, the youth training allowance and labour market programs. Never before has Australian unemployed youth been so carefully looked after with such a broad and comprehensive range of federal government measures. The youth training allowance will eventually totally replace the jobsearch allowance for Australians under the age of 18. It will mean that people in this category concentrate on the only possible recipe for future success—that is, training for the work force.

It is my belief that case management is the single most effective aspect of this package of measures. Young people not only respond well to, but need, one-on-one contact. Just as the best training is given on a one-to-one basis, the best help is given on a one-to-one basis. Assistance in this area is something I feel particularly close to and feel very strongly about. As some people in this place know, my background lies in training. Immediately prior to entering the parliament, I ran a job club in Launceston training the unemployed under my business, Multiskill.

I know that many people on the other side of the Committee are going to run the argument, when they speak on this bill, that there is no use in training people for jobs that do not exist and that the only reason the government is interested in training is that it hides the true levels of the unemployed. Let me inform the Committee that these arguments do not have any validity at all, especially for anyone who has worked in that kind of environment. The job club that I ran in Launceston had an 80 per cent success rate in assisting our students to gain work. Organisations in my electorate, such as Northern Joblink, Launceston Skillshare, Glenara Skillshare and others, are still being very successful. I commend them and the work that they do for the young people and the people who are seeking employment.

The role that training plays in achieving employment outcomes cannot be devalued. It is absolutely critical. I would like to take a moment here to mention a couple of cases that have come to mind as being quite outstanding. For example, I can remember a young man coming to me who was, I imagine, about 17 1/2 at that stage. His name was Gareth and he had absolutely no direction in his life at 17 1/2. He had done a little bit of hospitality training but it really was not him. So he came along to the job club, firstly, to be with other people who were seeking employment and, secondly, to see if he could find some direction in his life.

We opened up all sorts of possibilities. At school he had done some computer training and he had rather enjoyed that. Part of my company was a bank of computers, 12 computers, and we ran computer training programs, so we sent him on to computer training. He became so good at it that he landed a part-time job with Nestle. He has continued on that part-time job. He sometimes has 20 hours a week—his minimum is 20—and sometimes he has 35 hours a week. But he is extremely happy with what he has been able to achieve. He has a goal, he has a direction, he knows where he is going in life.

After he left me at the job club, before his job eventuated, he continued that contact back to the job club, because I gave every student that came to me that one-on-one training contact and assurance that I would never let them down. I do not know sometimes whether it works to be beneficial, to give that one-on-one, because Gareth has now ended up being my youngest daughter's boyfriend.

We have also had many young people that came into other programs that I ran through Multiskill. I can remember a group of young students that had been selected by the police and corrective services for this particular program. We thought, `Golly, what are we going to do with these young people?' So it was a motivational program. But many of those young people then went on to other training. Some went into hospitality, some went to TAFE. A couple actually went back and matriculated, and one also went on to computer studies. They made some decisions because people cared, because government put things into place for them to access programs far more easily.

The youth training allowance is going to move the benefits for the young unemployed into a tighter and closer relationship with the assistance which is available under Austudy. All those sorts of things come into place to assist our young people and we must never, ever let those programs disintegrate. This relationship is closest with regard to the parental means test and the away from home rate of benefit. The youth training allowance does, however, still retain the same general conditions as for jobsearch allowance.

The Department of Employment, Education and Training will have the policy responsibility for the youth training allowance. I particularly commend this initiative. It is this department which is best set up and has the best skills to deal with a program which uses a training focus to foster and deliver an employment related outcome. This really is an example of horses for courses, with the Department of Social Security remaining the pay agency for the youth training allowance. The youth training allowance is a hybrid. It has been born because the government has seen and responded to a specific need. It takes the best methods of service, focus and delivery from each of the departments of Social Security and Employment, Education and Training. It is without doubt one of the best examples of this federal government highlighting an area of specific need and responding to it.

The measures of this bill are drafted to specifically fit its target group. The liquid assets test will be made fairer. It will allow for the proceeds of the sale of a person's home to be deducted in the liquid assets test if that money is used to buy another home.

Current provisions allow for the payment of youth training allowance to continue for up to three weeks after the individual commences an Austudy or Abstudy approved course for longer than six months. This is currently dependent on the determination of the person's claim for student assistance payment. This bill allows for that payment to continue for the full three weeks, regardless of course duration. As well as this measure it provides relief from the activity test during these circumstances.

At this point I would like to give an overview of the central component of the youth training initiative. One of the most important components of the youth training initiative is access—access to labour market programs. Young people who are assessed as being in this category of high risk of long-term unemployment have instant access to the full spectrum of labour market programs. Those not assessed as being in the high risk category have access to labour market programs after 26 weeks. I commend that initiative. Having been in this area of training, I know that it will make things a lot easier for the young people out there who are desperate to do something with their lives. The most important point to make here is that the government is making every endeavour to make sure that those most at risk are targeted early and helped early.

The type of labour market programs is also very important. The programs are designed to be most relevant to the needs of their target group. They include wage subsidies for jobs under the national wage training award, work experience and training through the land care and environment action program, training through accredited training for youth and something that is reflective of my background—jobsearch assistance through job clubs and formal training options. That has to be an absolute bonus.

New work opportunities will also be available from 1 July this year to clients who have been in receipt of youth training allowances for six months. The youth training initiative will also give early assistance into traineeships and apprenticeships. There will be 60,000 new apprenticeship places in the next financial year, as well as 34,000 new traineeship places, an initiative that needs to be commended. There are many young people out there seeking apprenticeship places and traineeship places, but they have not been available, so this will be a very good option for them.

Another extremely good initiative is the expansion in pre-vocational courses to 15,000 places. Prior to my working with job club, I worked with TAFE and I know how special the pre-vocational courses run at the TAFE colleges are for the young people to go on into the work places. These new places are needed and, better still, they are targeted to those who are in need of the general and vocational skills which are required to gain employment.

As at the end of April this year, over 4,500 young Australians under the youth training initiative had commenced labour market programs. This also included almost 900 traineeships. So the march has begun. I think it should be highlighted that only those who are registered as unemployed are eligible for the youth training allowance. There have been cases of some students applying for the allowance when they enrol in courses after not having been registered with the CES. In these circumstances, such people can be referred by the CES to labour market programs that involve vocational training. If, at the end of the course, they have not found employment, the CES will continue to provide assistance.

There is also the question of whether someone can continue to receive youth training allowance for longer than six months. In most cases, the youth training allowance will be payable to people who attend courses that are of six months or less and Austudy will be payable for courses that are longer than six months. However, some labour market programs are greater than six months. In these cases, if people have been referred to that program by the CES they will continue to be paid the youth training allowance. The youth training allowance is the basic plank of the youth training initiative because it provides the income support needed to make the program function.

To be eligible for the youth training allowance there are a number of basic criteria. People must be 16 or 17, they must be registered as unemployed with the CES and they must not be in receipt of jobsearch allowance. Fifteen-year-olds are only eligible if they live away from home, are unsupported and are experienced in the labour force. This essentially means that they must have a work history or 13 weeks registration as unemployed.

The allowance is paid in three rates. There is an at-home rate which is paid up to a maximum of $134.60 per fortnight and a minimum rate of $62.90. The away from home rate is for those who need to live away from home in order to undertake jobsearch activities or approved training. This is payable at a maximum rate of $222.10 per fortnight and a minimum rate of $62.90 per fortnight. There is also an independent rate which includes homeless clients. This is payable at the rate of $222.10 per fortnight, plus rent allowance.

As of 19 May 20,273 young people were in receipt of youth training allowance. All of those figures, and all of the statements that I have made, prove to me, and I trust to the rest of the House, that the student assistance amendment bill which we are discussing today is well worth while and will always be well worth while. I commend it to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In summing up, I thank those members who have taken part in the debate. There are a few matters which I really should address and which were raised in the address by the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), who was critical of the second reading speech for its bureaucratic and excessively legalistic tone and language. I take the opportunity to point out to him the obvious—which he seems to need to have pointed out to him quite frequently—that we are talking about a complex legal instrument.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about people's rights and obligations under a range of circumstances that can frequently generate quite complex matters. For that reason, we need clarity and precision, because many of the decisions about people's income support can be subject to appeal. The honourable member for Goldstein is, I am sure, aware of that; but, in view of his remarks, I feel that I should place that matter on the record. None of the language in the second reading speech detracts from the fact that the youth training initiative is part of this government's vision for Australia's young people.

Above all, this is a government that has been responsible for opening up opportunities for young people. We would all be aware that, when the government came to office, fewer than one in three young people completed secondary school. It is now three out of every four who complete their schooling. When this government came to office, there were 16 universities in Australia, almost exclusively located in capital cities. There are now 37 or 38, and the undergraduate population has expanded by some 60 per cent in the last 12 years of Labor government.

At the same time, of course, we have worked very hard to expand opportunities in TAFE and skills training. This year in the budget, the government is providing over $1 billion, through the states, to expand opportunities in TAFE and training. Honourable members will be interested in one figure: when TAFE and training institutions open their doors in term 1 of next year, there will be 300,000 extra students there because of the additional funding that this government has provided. There will be 300,000 students over and above what the states provide for.

Of course, as honourable members have pointed out, from then on, armed with skills that are relevant to, and required by, industry, young people these days can feel increasingly confident about their prospects of moving on into employment—and not into the dead-end jobs that technological change has seen disappear, but into rewarding, interesting and stimulating careers. In other words, this is a government which has transformed opportunities available for young people.

I have listened, in the last 10 days or so, to opposition members talking about `battlers': a species which they seem to have discovered only in recent times. I submit that the real battlers are those young people who could not, during the time of the coalition's period in office, get an education and could not get the skills that industry required to lead on to interesting jobs. Of course, youth unemployment is still too high, but people should be aware of what the statistics mean when they talk about them. Most young people in the age group of 15 to 19 are not in the labour market, but are at school or university or TAFE, or are in training.

It is true that, for the small numbers of 15- to 19-year-olds who are in the labour market, job prospects are pretty bleak. This is as you would expect, because these are the young people who do not have the skills that industry requires, and because the kinds of unskilled jobs that used to be available to the early school-leavers of 15 years ago and earlier have disappeared as a result of technological change. So youth unemployment is high, but it is a high percentage of a small number, if one measures youth unemployment as a percentage of the age group. I suggest that the 15- to 19-year-olds are a special case, given that so many of them are in education. If one takes that second measure of unemployment as a percentage of those in the age cohort, one sees that that figure, month by month, is roughly the same as unemployment across the entire community. In fact, in recent times, I think it is somewhat less.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are bluffing.
—I do my best to help my innumerate friends opposite. I suggest that they have a look at the statistics of the Department of Employment, Education and Training and, particularly, that figure.

PARA.TAB: The objective of the youth training initiative is to remove unemployment as an option for young people. It aims to provide them with structured training that is relevant to the needs of industry—training that will lead them on to employment, and will give them credit transfer into further qualifications. It aims to provide them, at the same time, with income support—that is, essentially, what this bill deals with—and to provide them with case management.

I take on board the comments of the honourable member for Goldstein about the way in which the Commonwealth Employment Service sometimes deals with young clients. The Commonwealth Employment Service recognises that it faces a special challenge in this area. That is why it has been government policy to establish as many youth access centres as we can across the country, to make the face of the Commonwealth Employment Service more acceptable, more welcoming and more relevant to young people. Where those youth access centres have been established, they have been able to do the job a little better—in many cases, a lot better—than the normal Commonwealth Employment Service job centre has been able to do.

The problem has also been recognised by the government in its case management response. The job of the case managers is to work with young people, to agree on what each young person wants and needs in order to gain the skills to get a job. Case managers recognise that young people on the youth training allowance may not have completed a full secondary education. Therefore, part of their task is to undertake a detailed needs assessment of those young people, so that they are able to make flexible and appropriate use of labour market programs, and to help them.

It might be a question of attending to their basic literacy and numeracy needs, for example. It might be a matter of providing transport assistance. It might be a matter of arranging specialist counselling. The kind of assistance that has been provided in a pilot form under the JPET program—to which the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) referred—is being embraced under the case management regime. The essential element of case management which particularly applies to young people—who, I agree, all too often suffer a sense of alienation—is working on a one-to-one basis and working with the particular person.

Finally, I was a little mystified by the honourable member for Goldstein's concern that this bill may not have been appropriately referred to the Main Committee for consideration. I am told that matters are only referred to this chamber when there is an agreement between government and opposition. That is what I am told. If there is a problem, I think it is probably one that the honourable member for Goldstein should take up with the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Reith).
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The government amendments will add provisions to the bill in relation to compensation recovery and the parental income test. I will turn to compensation recovery first.

PARA.TAB: The compensation recovery provisions in division 12 of part VIII of the act seek to avoid dual payments of income support and compensation in certain circumstances. The government amendments would make changes to schedule 4 of the bill, which contains amendments to the compensation recovery provisions in division 12 of part VIII of the act. The government amendments would ensure that payments of certain types of pensions, benefits or allowances which were paid to a person's partner under the Social Security Act 1991 but had been superseded by other types of pensions, benefits and allowances could be recovered under the compensation recovery provisions.

The government amendments would also simplify the compensation recovery rules in section 229 and 233 of the act. Currently, the compensation recovery provisions require a person to be qualified for youth training allowance. Therefore, a decision must first be made about whether a person is qualified for the payment, even though it may be obvious from the person's circumstances that he or she will be precluded from payment because of the compensation recovery provisions. However, a claimant for the allowance and the department are each put to the inconvenience and cost of qualification assessment for no practical purpose. These amendments would remove the requirement that a person be qualified for youth training allowance before the compensation recovery provisions can operate. The government's amendments which relate to compensation recovery are similar to other amendments already made by the bill to other provisions of division 12 of part A.

Turning to the parental income test, the government's amendments would also remove a technical difficulty which has been discovered in the application of the loan fringe benefits provisions of the parental income test. That test is relevant to calculating the rate at which the person receives youth training allowance. For these provisions to operate properly, a yearly notional interest rate should have been prescribed by regulation. No regulation was made. If a regulation had been made, the rates would have been the same as the rates inserted by schedule 11. The need for a regulation in the future has been removed by the amendments to be made by schedule 11. Any possible anomalies in the manner in which the loan fringe benefits provision have been currently applied are to be removed by the government amendments.

There are very few young people affected by the loan fringe benefit provisions of the parental income test. If any of them received youth training allowance at a higher rate than is provided for by these amendments, no repayment would be required. If any of them would have been entitled to a higher rate, but did not receive it, the amendments permit any shortfall to be paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in my main remarks, we have had an opportunity to look at the government's proposed additional amendments and we do not intend to oppose them. I made the comment then, and I repeat it now, that the fact that additional amendments are still coming through at this late stage only reinforces the view that this whole Heath Robinsonesque system which the government is constructing in its efforts to help unemployed people is being invented on the run. I am afraid that is not good enough. It is causing a great deal of confusion in the community. One would have hoped that, by this time, the government would have got its act together on Working Nation.

PARA.TAB: I also make the point that there will be further amendments moved by the opposition in the Senate in relation to this legislation, because the Senate will be moving amendments and possibly making amendments to social security legislation which this piece of legislation mirrors in part. So we will see a continuing debate on the proper form of this bill. It is important that the measures which the government is putting forward in these additional amendments and in the main bill be seen to effectively assist unemployed people, particularly unemployed young people, and recognise the seriousness of the problem. In every other area of statistics, and particularly the unemployment statistics, the government sticks scrupulously to international definitions of unemployment. By those definitions, if a person is employed one hour during the week, that person is considered as employed and not unemployed. The government makes sure that that definition is implemented and reported by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

Indeed, it is the case, I understand, that if a person is employed one hour in the course of a year, that person cannot be considered under those definitions to be long-term unemployed, even though that person may be unemployed for the whole of the remainder of the year. That one hour's employment cuts that person out of the statistics. This is part of the general rigging of the statistics, from the point of view of giving the public an accurate impression, although the government will defend itself on the basis that these are the rigorous international definitions. Yet, in relation to youth unemployment, we saw the minister attempting to minimise this problem by a new definition—

TALK.START.PARA: —A home-grown definition.

—As the honourable member for Gippsland so rightly says, it is a home-grown definition of youth unemployment, which suddenly makes the problem `disappear'. I do not want to stray from the matter before this Committee. These additional amendments are simply part of a system the government has put in place in an effort to make it appear as though it is addressing a problem which the minister thinks is perhaps not a terribly serious problem at all. I can assure the minister that we will remind him of his statement on that matter in the House and, I am sure, during the forthcoming election campaign, whenever it will be.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 11 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 contains a range of measures announced in the budget to amend the provisions of the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 relating to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The amendments are principally designed to tighten the eligibility criteria for rebates of customs or excise duty which have been paid on purchases of diesel fuel, so that the integrity of the scheme as it was introduced in 1982 to assist those engaged in mainstream primary production and those engaged in mainstream mining operations can be maintained.

PARA.TAB: During the last year in particular, as a result of a series of legal challenges, eligibility definitions in the scheme have been subjected to considerable expansion. This has pointed to ambiguities in the interpretation of these definitions, which demand urgent remedial attention so as to prevent the exploitation of the scheme and a consequential drain on the public purse.
The four principal changes to the scheme proposed by the bill involve:

SPEECH.PARA: (I)the abolition of the `residential premises' category from rebate eligibility, from 1 July 1995;

(II)the confirmation of the definition of `agriculture' in the Customs Act 1901 to exclude from rebate eligibility activities which might loosely be described under the phrase `amenity agriculture', from 1 August 1986;

(III)the narrowing of the definition of `minerals' in the Customs Act 1901 so as to exclude from rebate eligibility diesel fuel used in the mining for minerals, where those operations simply involve the extraction of sand, sandstone, soil, clay, granite, water and the like, from 1 August 1986; and

(IV)the amendment of the definitions of `agriculture' and `mining operations' in the Customs Act 1901 to specify a clear list of activities in which the use of diesel fuel is to be eligible for the payment of rebate, from 1 August 1986.

PARA.EMPHASIS: I)Abolition of the category of `residential premises'

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this amendment is to reduce government outlays by limiting rebate eligibility to diesel fuel used for residential premises on agricultural properties and in mining operations.

The Government has been mindful that the removal of rebate eligibility for this category may present an additional financial burden on the operation of farming properties and on individuals engaging in mining operations. For these reasons, rebate will continue to be paid on diesel fuel purchased for use for domestic purposes:

SPEECH.PARA: .at residential premises on the farms of individuals engaging in agriculture; and
.at residential premises of individuals engaging in mining operations.

In proposing this amendment, the government has also been mindful of the adverse effects the abolition of this category would have on indigenous communities in Australia. As a result, separate compensation arrangements in the order of $1.8 million per year will be put in place to ensure that indigenous communities are not disadvantaged by the change.

PARA.TAB: The proposed abolition of the category of `residential premises' and the introduction of the new and related categories under `agriculture' and `mining operations' in items 1, 2, 3, 5, 6 and 9 of schedule 1 to the bill are proposed to have effect in respect of diesel fuel purchased on or after 1 July 1995. Diesel fuel purchased before 1 July 1995 will continue to be rebatable under the current legislative provisions. Recurring savings as a result of these measures are in the order of $11.8 million per year.

The remaining three amendments proposed by the bill are intended to clarify the ambit and integrity of the scheme as it was introduced in 1982. The government is firmly of the view that the scheme was never intended to pay rebate on diesel fuel used in activities that might only loosely be described as encouraging mining operations or primary production in a general sense. Rather, in the government's view, the scheme was designed to pay rebate to primary producers who use diesel fuel in the act of growing or gathering in of crops, or the rearing of livestock, and in other activities that are sufficiently connected with agriculture or, in relation to mining operations, to pay rebate for fuel used in the act of exploring or prospecting for minerals, and their subsequent mining and beneficiation, or in the liquefaction of natural gas or the production of common salt. The series of three amendments described below proceed on that basis, as follows:

PARA.EMPHASIS: II)Confirming the scope of the definition of `agriculture'

PARA.TAB: Last year, an appeal was heard by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against a decision of the Australian Customs Service to refuse the payment of rebate on diesel fuel used to carry out `amenity agriculture', such as the mowing of lawns and sports grounds and the maintenance of golf courses. In September 1994, the tribunal decided that the decision of Customs to not pay rebate was correct, but the matter is currently on appeal to the Federal Court. Items 4 and 10 of schedule 1 to the bill are proposed to remove any doubt that these kinds of activities are intended to fall outside of the act's definition of `agriculture', and thus are not to be given the benefit of rebate.

These particular amendments will ensure the continuation of rebate payments for diesel fuel used in carrying out agricultural activities for the purposes of a business undertaken to obtain produce for sale. At the same time, they will ensure that amenity agriculture of the type carried out by local or state governments, parks and gardens organisations and sporting clubs and individuals is excluded from the definition of `agriculture' in the act.

Because these issues have arisen as a result of efforts by users of diesel fuel to broaden the scope of the scheme well beyond what the government believes was intended, the government is proposing that this amendment be made retrospective to 1 August 1986, in order to protect the revenue. It is from this date that purchases of diesel fuel made after that date can be claimed.

Without such retrospectivity, there is a likelihood that claims which are pending the outcome of a Federal Court appeal will result in the payment of rebate of up to $40 million. In addition, recurring savings in the order of $15 million per year are anticipated from this change.

Until recently, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court have held the view that the term `mining for minerals' in the act's definition of `mining operations' introduced a purposive test requiring a rebate claimant to demonstrate that the purpose of the claimant's operations was to obtain a mineral or minerals embedded in the material that was extracted. For instance, there was a clear distinction between the extraction of sand per se and the extraction of sand with a view to obtaining from it minerals such as rutile, zircon or almandite.

The meaning of `mining operations' was therefore considered to be reasonably well settled until a recent decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on the issue of extracting sand for use in the making of concrete or for use as bedding sand in the construction industry. The tribunal decided that the extraction of such sand was eligible for rebate. Claims have also been received for rebate on diesel fuel used in the pumping of ground water to be supplied as drinking water to towns. These are, in the government's view, uses well beyond the intent of the scheme, which was and is to deliver an assistance measure to mainstream mining pursuits.

Accordingly, in item 7 of schedule 1 to the bill, the government has proposed to amend the definition of `minerals' to exclude sand, sandstone, soil, slate, clay (other than bentonite or kaolin), basalt, granite, gravel, limestone and water. The exclusion is consistent with the principal mining legislation of the states and would bring about a transparent distinction between mining for minerals and operations that cannot, in the ordinary sense, be regarded as mining. Where these materials are extracted for the purpose of recovering a mineral, the extraction will remain eligible for rebate.

The government is proposing that this amendment be made retrospective to 1 August 1986, in order to protect the revenue. Without such retrospectivity, there is a likelihood that the claim which is pending the outcome of a Federal Court appeal will result in the payment of rebate of up to $91 million. In addition, recurring savings in the order of $20 million are anticipated from this change.

PARA.EMPHASIS: IV)The amendment of the definitions of `agriculture' and `mining operations' to specify a clear list of activities in which the use of diesel fuel is to be eligible for the payment of rebate

PARA.TAB: In the existing legislation, both the definition of `agriculture' and the definition of `mining operations' employ what are known as `sweeper clauses'—

EMPHASIS.TAB: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from midday to 12.11 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the break for the division, in the existing legislation, both the definition of `agriculture' and the definition of `mining operations' employ what are known as `sweeper clauses', which have the effect of making other operations connected with agriculture or mining eligible for the payment of rebate. The interpretation of these `sweeper clauses' has been a main source of contention over the years, and has generated most of the litigation in the lifetime of the scheme.

PARA.TAB: The amendments proposed in items 4 and 8 of schedule 1 to the bill are to remove the subjectivity associated with the `sweeper clauses', and to replace those clauses with an objective list of activities that are eligible for rebate. This has been done with a view to giving claimants certainty as to the actual activities that are eligible for rebate, and thereby avoiding the costly litigation concerning eligibility circumstances which has plagued the scheme in recent years.

It should be noted that, although the proposed amendments will necessarily narrow the range of activities for which rebate is payable, farmers and miners will generally be unaffected. The intention of these amendments is to put beyond doubt that the scheme is not meant to provide rebate eligibility for activities which are not sufficiently connected with mining or agriculture; for instance, the provision of a service or utility to a farmer or miner, such as electricity through a grid, or the building of a dam which is intended to supply water to, amongst others, farmers, or the operation of a garbage tip on a former mine site by someone other than the miner, where the resultant filling of the mine site is said to be the rehabilitation of a mine site, and thus connected with a mining operation.

Because claims of these kinds have sought to broaden the scheme well beyond what it should be, the government is proposing that these amendments be made retrospective to 1 August 1986, in order to protect the revenue. Without such retrospectivity, there is a likelihood that claims which are pending the outcome of several Federal Court appeals and one High Court application will result in the payment of rebate of up to $30 million. In addition, recurring savings in the order of $7 million are anticipated from these changes.

It is noted with regard to the 3 proposed series of amendments which I have outlined and which it is proposed have a retrospective commencement, that any rebates that have been paid since 1 August 1986 are to remain intact, and are to be treated as validly paid. This is explicitly stated in clause 5 of the bill.
The amendments proposed in this bill are expected to result in the following savings to the revenue, in present dollar values;

SPEECH.PARA: I)Abolition of the category of residential premises
.savings for 1995-96 of $13.6 million, offset by compensation arrangements to the value of $1.8 million;
II)Confirming the scope of the definition of `agriculture'
.one-off retrospective savings of $40 million on claims under review or unpaid;

PARA.TAB: .savings for 1995-96 of $15 million;

SPEECH.PARA: III)Narrowing the definition of `minerals'
.one-off retrospective savings of $91 million on claims under review or unpaid;

PARA.TAB: .savings for 1995-96 of $20 million;

SPEECH.PARA: IV)amendment of the definitions of `agriculture' and `mining operations' to remove the sweeper clauses
.one-off retrospective savings of $30 million on claims under review or unpaid;

PARA.TAB: .savings for 1995-96 of $7 million.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the bill to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —On budget night, the government proudly and loudly declared that it would leave the diesel fuel rebate scheme intact. After the controversy and the public debate leading up to budget night, with industry fearing that the diesel fuel rebate scheme would be curtailed or even abolished, the government's announcement was met with a great deal of relief and was endorsed by industry.

PARA.TAB: However, we now find that several substantial changes have been proposed by the government to determine eligibility for claiming rebates under the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The present structure of the scheme dates from 1 August 1986 and gives a rebate of petroleum products excise to certain classes of off-road diesel users. Originally, petroleum products excise was intended to pay for road funding, but as road funding now comprises only eight per cent of the total revenue from the excise, the link is irretrievably broken.

With the breakdown of hypothecation, the excise is best considered as an intermediate tax on a business input. That is how this debate should be framed. Any alterations to the diesel fuel rebate scheme is a change to an intermediate business input. At present, the excise on diesel fuel in round figures is 32.5c per litre. The government expects to recoup $3.9 billion from diesel excise alone in 1995-96, which is an increase of nine per cent on the previous year.

Under the scheme, eligible primary producers receive a rebate of the full excise, namely 32.5c per litre, while eligible mining operations receive a rebate of 30.1c per litre, so effectively they pay an excise of 2.4c per litre. Other rebatable users receive a rebate of 24.8c per litre, so effectively they pay 7.8c per litre in excise.

Turning to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 which is now before the chamber, I wish to consider the aspect of retrospectivity, as there are retrospective elements of this bill common to several measures. We need to consider this issue separately.

As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay) outlined in the second reading speech, the government argues that retrospectivity is required to limit its liability from piggyback claims. These claims arise because decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court have broadened the scope of eligible rebatable activities beyond that originally intended. This gives other claimants the opportunity to claim rebates they were not eligible for before the relevant AAT or court decision.

There are several points to consider. Revenue is the prime motive for this retrospectivity, as acknowledged by the government in the second reading speech. Increasing imposts on business is more electorally saleable for the Labor government than increasing other taxes. On the government's own estimates, it will gain at least $86 million retrospectively from these measures. So the government's prime motivation is revenue raising.

The retrospectivity extends nine years, to 1 August 1986. I would have thought that was ample time and gave plenty of opportunity to clarify the operation of the scheme. Retrospective legislation brings uncertainty to the environment in which business operates, particularly where the motive is unambiguously revenue raising. Good government demands a predictable framework for investment. The bill before the chamber will overturn several decisions of the AAT and the courts, to the financial disadvantage of the claimants, and will abort other decisions in process.
Mr Lindsay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it will, because if someone has a claim before the AAT or the court at the moment, that will be it, it will be terminated.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lindsay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —For those successful claimants to the AAT or court the message will be, `Well done, you can keep the money.' The government has no intention of seeking the rebate from them.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lindsay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —But what about all those claimants who have gone to the considerable expense of exercising their legal right to challenge legislation? They will be cut off in midstream, and there is no suggestion by the government that it will compensate claimants for the legal expenses incurred to date. So I just cannot accept the government's discrimination against claimants according to the stage of legal proceedings. If you have completed it, you are home and hosed; if you are under way at present, you are cut off at the socks.

PARA.TAB: Surely the entitlement to test the meaning of legislation before the AAT or courts is fundamental to our legal system, it is at the heart of an individual's or a company's rights. After all, there is no element of illegality or fraud to justify the retrospectivity, as there was for the removal of the bottom of the harbour tax schemes. Companies have gone to considerable expense to contest decisions in the AAT and courts which will be overturned now by this legislation. In effect, industry is being asked to pay for the consequences of poorly drafted eligibility provisions and government inaction for nine years. Therefore, the coalition opposes the retrospectivity elements of the legislation and the coalition in the Senate will move to amend the measures to commence at 7.30 p.m. on 9 May 1995, being the budget announcement. We accept that it is appropriate to follow the convention of making the measures retrospective to budget night to contain any windfall gains.

Looking now at the specific proposals of the bill in the same order that the parliamentary secretary did, the abolition of the category of residential premises will start from 1 July 1995, so there is no contentious retrospectivity here. The measure effectively removes the eligibility of residential premises for rebate, except those residential premises associated with agriculture and mining. To offset the added impost on remote indigenous communities, the parliamentary secretary has announced compensation measures of $1.8 million per year.

We have got a number of problems with this. The first and major one is that we have not been told, because the government either cannot or will not tell us, how many individuals in remote and rural communities will be affected. We already know that the government concedes that the indigenous communities will need compensation, but what about non-Aboriginal Australians? Until we get that information, we are not prepared to support this measure. We do know from Customs, in some of the excellent briefings it has provided, that, of the total of approximately 14,500 claims received in 1992-93 under this category, 13,500 are individuals. The remaining 1,000 claimants are largely hospitals, nursing homes, medical institutions and aged care homes.

Customs advises me that it believes that the private individuals, the 13,500 we speak of, tend to be in the cities or larger centres. Otherwise they would usually claim the agricultural rebate, if living in rural or remote areas. But we are not convinced of that. We have received some anecdotal advice from rural communities and farmers' groups that there are a great many more individuals in rural and remote areas claiming this diesel rebate than Customs may think. Customs has done its best to identify the groups affected, other than indigenous communities, as companies providing crew quarters on coastal trading ships, council run caravan parks or workers' camps, resort proprietors providing staff accommodation, prison services, staff accommodation provided by state governments, private caravan parks, private ski clubs and private individuals.

So we are still very short on detail. It is the opposition's intention to refer this issue to a Senate Friday committee to allow potentially affected groups to put their case. We will, by way of amendment, if there are a large number of rural and remote individuals affected, move an amendment in the Senate so that they continue to receive the diesel fuel rebate, on the basis that they have no alternative energy source. We accept and understand that the diesel fuel rebate should no longer be available for urban residential premises—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not give them the subsidy?

—Or give them the subsidy as the Industry Commission report No. 40 of July 1994 on petroleum products recommended. The commission recommended the total abolition of the diesel fuel rebate scheme and said that it believed that a subsidy should be given, as has been done for indigenous communities. We believe that by way of either subsidy or the rebate scheme we should continue to provide for those who have no alternative energy source to diesel fuel generators. In urban areas there is an alternative in reticulated gas lines or electricity.

PARA.TAB: That is the purpose of the Friday Senate hearing and it may be, as the parliamentary secretary interjected, that it would be better to provide for those remote and isolated rural dwellers by way of subsidy. That is something that we are happy to consider but we draw a distinction between those two categories of people.

Looking now at the exclusion of amenity agriculture from the definition of agricultural activities eligible for rebate, this measure is to be retrospective to 1 August 1986, and I have already spoken on that issue. The coalition will oppose the retrospectivity element of this part of the bill. However, we will support the remainder of the measure. We do not oppose future abolition of the rebate for amenity agriculture for the reasons the parliamentary secretary has outlined.

Of course, the amendment before the chamber was prompted by a claim for rebate made by the city of Nunawading in September 1994 for mowing reserves and nature strips. The government won in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal but the case is now on appeal in the Federal Court and we believe that should be able to proceed. However, we are as concerned as the government that there not be any future expansion of the diesel fuel rebate scheme for amenity agriculture.
