Looking now at the third section of the bill, narrowing the definition of minerals, again it is to be retrospective from 1 August 1986, which we oppose. Moreover, we oppose the measure. We have thought long and hard about this and have decided that there is no fundamental reason why some extractive industries should be provided with diesel fuel rebates and others not. We do not accept the delineation between quarrying and mining that the government proposes. I have taken advice on this and the methodology involved in quarrying is identical in almost all respects, if not all respects, to open-cut mining. So we believe the operations involved in quarrying are so identical to those carried out in mining operations that they should continue to receive the rebate.

Looking now at the fourth and final section of the bill, the tightening of definitions of agricultural and mining operations, again the measure is to be retrospective to 1 August 1986, which we will oppose in the Senate. The amendments will define tightened lists of activities eligible for rebate relating to mining and agriculture so that rebate for agricultural activities will be restricted to diesel fuel purchased for use in preparation of the soil, the act of growing primary produce or rearing of livestock and other connected activities. Rebate for mining activities will be restricted to exploring, prospecting, subsequent treatment and processing of minerals and other activities such as the liquefaction of natural gas and production of salt by evaporation.

There is a fair bit of confusion in just how this amendment will operate. There are a number of legal opinions still being obtained and being presented by the mining and agricultural industries on the interpretation of the legislation. There are some representations being made by the mining industry that this measure will reduce payments of rebate currently allowed for rehabilitation of mining operations, transport activities, pumping of water and the generation of electricity. The parliamentary secretary has gone some way to allaying fears in his second reading speech when he argued that the proposed amendments, whilst narrowing the range of activities for which the rebate is payable, will not affect those activities which are sufficiently connected with mining or agriculture.

He gave examples which I could agree with. The first was the provision of electricity through a grid. We would not believe that the diesel fuel rebates should be available for that activity. He included the building of a dam which is intended to supply water to, amongst others, farmers. We also would not believe that that is sufficiently connected to genuine mining or agricultural activities. However, he gives another example that I would like to take further advice on, just to illustrate that this is not yet a settled point, at least not so far as the coalition is concerned.

He gives the example `the operation of a garbage tip on a former mine site by someone other than the miner, where the resultant filling of the mine site is said to be the rehabilitation of a mine site, and thus connected with a mining operation.' At first glance, if the mining company had made a contractual arrangement with an operator of a garbage tip to fill in the hole and so satisfy rehabilitation requirements of state authorities, that may well be a genuine activity connected to mining. After all, rehabilitation of mining sites is undoubtedly part of a mining venture. So we will support the narrowing of the eligibility for the rebate where there are clear-cut examples, but we will oppose reductions in the level of rebate paid to genuine mining operations. So we still have some work—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who decides it is genuine?

—We will decide in between here and the Senate. There is still a fair bit of work ahead of us as the interpretations of the bill's provisions are made available to us. But at the moment we are not satisfied that the legislation will curtail only non-mining activities. For instance, there is one legal opinion which states that a train carrying ore from Mount Tom Price in the Pilbara to Port Hedland would receive the diesel fuel rebate, but on the return journey, the ore having been off-loaded, the train would not receive the diesel fuel rebate on the basis that it is not engaged in a mining activity.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the rebate available for agricultural activities, here too, there are some serious differences of interpretation. We have advice that the agricultural industry will be hit in regard to contractors operating on properties. For instance, a contractor transporting stock from one end of a large pastoral property to the other will not receive the diesel fuel rebate, and some questions have been raised in regard to other off-road activities. The Customs Service has been very good in providing some legal advice on these issues, but I have to advise the government that it has not satisfied some of our experts.

For this reason, we also wish to refer this aspect of the legislation to a Senate Friday committee. We want to hold the government to its assurances that those involved in genuine agricultural activities will continue to receive the diesel fuel rebate. We would believe that a contractor acting in place of a farmer, or standing in the shoes of a farmer, should receive the diesel fuel rebate.

So in summary, in amending the eligibility provisions of the diesel fuel rebate scheme for farmers and miners, the bill unjustifiably attempts to retain past revenue by legislating retrospectively for nine years to override adverse decisions on rebate claims in the AAT in courts. As well, the bill effectively increases taxes on the essential export industries of mining and agriculture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the bill. This is a budget measure so it is always useful to start at the appropriate place, which is Budget Paper No. 1. In the course of his contribution, the previous speaker, the member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), referred to these measures as having revenue as their motive. Unfortunately for him, they actually turn up in the outlays section of the budget and that is a most appropriate first point. We are not talking about revenue here; we are talking about outlays. We are talking about writing a Commonwealth cheque and giving it to people.

PARA.TAB: The starting point for these provisions is Budget Paper No. 1, chapter 3, page 162 under mining and mineral resources. I will quote this for the benefit of the member for Gippsland and others. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Outlays under this function provide development assistance to the mining and manufacturing sectors to improve the efficiency and competitiveness of Australian industries.

The Commonwealth provides assistance in the form of grants, subsidies, bounties, direct project involvement, price support and adjustment schemes, contributions to research and promotion and export development costs, and services to industry provided by some departments and organisations either free of charge or at a charge which do not fully recover the costs involved.

In Budget Paper No. 1 there is a chart which shows the trends of outlays in this particular area. When we look at the trend shown on page 162 using 1989-90 dollars or prices as a constant, we find we are talking about anywhere between $1 billion to $2 billion of Commonwealth revenue. This particular year of the 1995-96 budget roughly comes in at about $1.7 billion. The budget paper continues:
The major influences on outlays trends between 1985-86 and 1998-99 include:
.an estimated increase in real terms of 9.7% in outlays in the mining sector mainly as a result of an increase in Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme (DFRS) payments to mining operators . . .

This one cannot be couched as being a measure which is perniciously taking everything away from this sector. This is a major Commonwealth outlay and we are talking about figures in the order of $1 billion to $2 billion of outlays. The budget paper is expressly referring to the diesel fuel rebate scheme on page 3.164. It says:

This Scheme provides for an excise rebate on diesel fuel used for off road purposes in mining operations. Outlays will increase during the period of the forward estimates as a result of increased consumption of diesel fuel and the effect of periodic indexation adjustment of the excise rate.
The DFRS will be amended to exclude from the scope of the scheme certain activities which are not considered to be genuine mining operations and were not part of the original scope of the scheme.

That gets to the heart of these measures. I have referred to the relevant extracts on the scheme in the outlays measures, but when we come to focus on the 1994-95 estimates for outlays in this particular area we find that the estimate for outlays for the rebate payments is in the order of $1.2 billion. That is the breadth and the scope of this scheme. When we look at the figures which are littered through the explanatory memorandum or the second reading speeches, we can see the small proportions that we are talking about in context.

PARA.TAB: Having put the matter in context for the benefit of my colleague and sometimes friend the member for Gippsland, let us get to the heart of these measures. In the end it gets down to the retrospective aspects. Retrospectivity is something which legislators should always approach with caution, but that is not to say that it should never be done, that there are never good reasons for doing it. As we go through the second reading speech of the parliamentary secretary, the intellectual rationale for the retrospectivity in this area is there. I want to quote from the parliamentary secretary's speech. At its beginning he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments are principally designed to tighten the eligibility criteria for rebates of customs or excise duty which have been paid on purchases of diesel fuel, so that the integrity of the scheme as it was introduced in 1982 to assist those engaged in mainstream primary production and those engaged in mainstream mining operations, can be maintained.

During the last year in particular, as a result of a series of legal challenges, eligibility definitions in the scheme have been subjected to considerable expansion. This has pointed to ambiguities in the interpretation of these definitions, which demand urgent remedial attention so as to prevent the exploitation of the scheme and a consequential drain on the public purse.

So what is the rationale for the retrospective aspects in this area? Again, I refer to the parliamentary secretary's words in the second reading speech where he talks about `the integrity of the scheme'; about ensuring that it `can be maintained'; about `eligibility definitions . . . have been subjected to considerable expansion'; about `ambiguities in the interpretation . . . which demand urgent remedial attention'. As we go through the parliamentary secretary's second reading speech, we find these themes constantly recurring. I again quote from his speech:

The government is firmly of the view that the scheme was never intended to pay rebate on diesel fuel used in activities that might only loosely be described as encouraging mining operations or primary production in a general sense. Rather, in the government's view, the scheme was designed to pay rebate to primary producers who use diesel fuel in the act of growing and gathering in of crops, or the rearing of livestock . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a Fraser government scheme.
—That is right. As the parliamentary secretary points out, the scheme enacted in 1982 was a Fraser government scheme. The sentence continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and in other activities that are sufficiently connected with agriculture or, in relation to mining operations, to pay rebate for fuel used in the act of exploring or prospecting for minerals, and their subsequent mining and beneficiation, or in the liquefaction of natural gas or the production of common salt.

The parliamentary secretary's second reading speech then refers to appeals and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The member for Gippsland said that those opposite would make up their minds on some of the detail of this between here and the Senate. Well, I assume they will go via the AAT or some other court rather than having the capacity to make these policy judgments themselves.

PARA.TAB: I again quote from the parliamentary secretary's second reading speech on the retrospectivity aspect. I do not think there is any dispute about those aspects of the bill which come into play on 1 July 1995. Towards the conclusion of his speech, the parliamentary secretary says:

SPEECH.PARA: The government is proposing that this amendment be made retrospective to 1 August 1986, in order to protect the revenue. Without such retrospectivity, there is a likelihood that the claim which is pending the outcome of a Federal Court appeal will result in the payment of rebate of up to $91 million. In addition, recurring savings in the order of $20 million are anticipated from this change.

He is there, of course, referring to the narrowing of the definition of minerals. He then goes through what are referred to as the `sweeper' clause and concludes, when he is dealing with the `sweeper' clause, by saying:

Because claims of these kinds have sought to broaden the scheme well beyond what it should be, the government is proposing that these amendments be made retrospective to 1 August 1986, in order to protect the revenue. Without such retrospectivity, there is a likelihood that claims which are pending the outcome of several Federal Court appeals and one High Court application will result in the payment of rebate of up to $30 million. In addition, recurring savings in the order of $7 million are anticipated from these changes.
It is noted with regard to the 3 proposed series of amendments which I have out

lined and which it is proposed have a retrospective commencement, that any rebates that have been paid since 1 August 1986 are to remain intact, and are to be treated as validly paid. This is explicitly stated in clause 5 of the bill.

I finish on that point because it is quite clear there is no effort or attempt at clawback here. This was one of the concerns raised directly with me by the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies representatives when I met with them late last week. It was made clear to the AMEC representatives, some from my own state of Western Australia, and this was a meeting which the parliamentary secretary and some relevant departmental officials were able to attend for some part. It was made absolutely clear that there is no attempt at clawback here.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lindsay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As the parliamentary secretary interjects, clause 5 makes that expressly and explicitly clear. So where have we got to in this particular measure? In the end it gets down to the retrospective aspect of the bill. As I said at the beginning, retrospectivity is something which should be treated with caution. That is not to say that it should never occur. People should only do it for good reason and when they do it they should do it in an up-front way. There is no question that the bill and the government have been absolutely up-front here. That was made expressly clear in the second reading speech when the parliamentary secretary, in his comments on the financial impact statement of this particular measure, referred to one-off retrospective savings.

PARA.TAB: There is no attempt to sneak some retrospective measure in here. There is no intent to retrospectively claw back from those claims that have already been decided on. There is no attempt at clawing back at all. In the end it gets down to whether, on balance, one believes that the integrity of the scheme, the retention of the integrity of the scheme, and the protection of the outlay and revenue aspects that follow from that, warrant or justify the retrospective application of these measures. In the government's view—and it is reflected by the bill—on balance, that is the case.

I referred earlier to representatives of AMEC having made some representations to me directly in the course of last week. In addition to the retrospective point which was part of their representations, they provided me with a paper, which I am sure other members have seen, of their concerns which go to two aspects. Some go to policy; others go to drafting of the particular bill itself. Together with the parliamentary secretary I was happy to ensure that representatives of AMEC were put directly with drafting officers from the relevant departments to see whether their concerns are drafting concerns which can be overcome or rectified between now and the introduction of the bill into the other place. Some of the concerns expressed by AMEC may well be solved by drafting measures.

I conclude where I started. This is a major area of outlays for the Commonwealth. We are talking of outlays between $1 billion and $2 billion—as I have gone through in Budget Paper No. 1. On the 1994-95 estimates for this particular scheme we are talking in terms of $1.2 billion. That puts these particular measures into context. The whole thrust of the retrospective measures that the bill contains is to ensure that the integrity of this scheme, as introduced, is held to that precise and particular purpose. The three series of amendments which affect that are, on balance, able to be applied in a retrospective way to ensure the integrity and principle of the scheme as introduced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 11 May this year. If in referring the bill to the Main Committee it was assumed to be non-contentious, I think the Chief Government Whip needs a new definition of `non-contentious'. The bill is very much in contention. For different reasons which the member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has outlined, the coalition opposes part of it and, for other reasons, seeks to have parts of it examined by a Senate committee. My focus is on one issue only: the bill effectively imposes taxes retrospectively.

PARA.TAB: Before 1982 diesel fuel used for off-road purposes was not subject to the payment of any customs duty or excise. This led to certain abuses in which untaxed diesel fuel became used for on-road consumption. To prevent loss of revenue and the abuse of the exemption, the government announced in the 1982-83 budget that excise would be imposed on all diesel fuel but a rebate would be allowed in respect of legitimate off-road use. Consumers eligible for the rebate included primary producers, miners and operators of residential nursing and aged persons homes.

The initial intention of the rebate scheme was to allow a full rebate of the excise paid for eligible users, but from 1983 various claimants were eligible for less than a 100 per cent rebate. In the 1994-95 budget, the estimated value of rebates payable to primary producers in that financial year was $515.7 million and for those conducting mining operations the rebate value was estimated at $632.1 million.

With this bill, the government proposes to make four amendments to the Customs Act 1901. The bill would remove the eligibility for the payment of rebate of customs duty in respect of the use of diesel fuel at residential premises. Secondly, the bill would narrow the definition of `minerals' in the Customs Act to exclude from rebate eligibility diesel fuel used in mining for materials that are more valuable for use in their own right—for example, sand, sandstone, soil, clay, granite and water—than for their inherent mineral worth. Thirdly, the bill seeks to ensure that rebate of customs and excise duty is payable only where the diesel fuel is for use in an activity strictly included in the definition of `agriculture' and not just in what is described as `amenity agriculture'. Finally, the proposals would remove from the definitions of `agriculture' and `mining operations' activities `connected with' mining and primary production, and insert a clear list of activities in which the use of diesel fuel is to be eligible for payment of rebate.
The bill also proposes amendments to the Excise Act 1901 to remove the eligibility for the payment of rebate of excise duty for diesel fuel used at residential premises.

It is to be noted that each of these amendments is in itself significant and substantive. They could not, by any stretch of imagination, be described merely as interpretations. They represent significant changes to the law defining the tax base.

The amendments removing customs duty would, if enacted, have effect retrospectively from 1 August 1986, the date on which the diesel fuel rebate scheme commenced. This extends the reach of the government's taxing grab back some nine years before this bill becomes law. The member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), who suggested that this bill is not a revenue raising measure, is merely quibbling with words, because effectively it is. It simply raises revenue by removing rebates on levies where the rebates have been paid up to now.
In the explanatory memorandum, the government states:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments are proposed to clarify the ambit of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme (DFRS) as being a targeted scheme intended to provide rebate of duty paid on diesel fuel used by those who are genuinely involved in the business of mining or farming, or those who undertake activities that are intimately bound up with mining or farming. This intention is implicit in paragraph 164(1)(a) and (aa) of the Customs Act, which provides that rebate is payable in respect of diesel fuel purchased for use in mining operations and in primary production.
I think I have already pointed out that this is not merely a clarification. The amendments that the government seeks to make are significant. The explanatory memorandum continues:

Rebate was originally intended to be payable to those who the ordinary person would have considered to be `farmers' and `miners'. However, as the years have progressed, various decisions of courts and tribunals have expanded the ambit of DFRS to the extent that many activities that should never have been regarded as being eligible to receive rebate have received, and continue to receive, rebate.

There can be no objection in principle to the government introducing amendments to a piece of legislation if it has become apparent that the judicial interpretation of the legislature's original intention as expressed in the statute does not reflect the government's current policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have been the Fraser government's policy, originally.

—We are not arguing about the original policy. The original policy was expressed in the language of the act as interpreted by the courts. But what the government is seeking to do here is to rewrite history. It has a penchant for rewriting history. It is doing it in this case in a way that takes away the rights of Australians, and takes away their money, retrospectively. Users of diesel fuel in the years since August 1986, when DFRS began, were entitled to arrange their affairs according to the law as it existed at the time, and as it has existed in the nine years that have ensued since then. It is a fundamental principle of our legal system that laws are made to have prospective operation and not retrospective operation. It is simply unjust and oppressive to subject citizens to a law they have no means of ascertaining simply because the law has not been conceived, drafted, debated or enacted.

PARA.TAB: It is not acceptable for the government to assert, as it does in the explanatory memorandum, that the law will have effect as if for the last nine years it had meant what, in the opinion of the author of the explanatory memorandum, a so-called `ordinary' person would have thought it meant. Under our legal system, laws mean what parliament intended them to mean. The task of deciding what parliament intended a particular law to mean, when there is any doubt about it, is entrusted to the courts.

Our system is a democracy subject to the rule of law. If the government cannot draft its legislation properly, it must redraft it and go forward from there. This attempt to rewrite history is outrageous and should be resisted. The Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills, referring to this particular bill, said, in respect of the retrospectivity, that this clearly trespasses on the basic right that those subject to the law are entitled to be treated according to what the law says at the relevant time and according to what the law means at that time as declared by the courts.

If the government is seeking to make these retrospective amendments to the law because it has been too lax to introduce prospective amendments years ago, then it has caused the revenue to forgo possible savings of $86 million. In the words of the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills:

SPEECH.PARA: The Financial Impact Statement in the explanatory memorandum indicates that the one-off retrospective savings amounting to $86 million are 3 times the $27 million savings for 1995-96 for the same categories.
The committee continues:

It would be a matter of grave concern if this position has been reached because for up to 3 years the executive has refrained from administering the rebate according to the law as declared by the courts, forcing applicants for the rebate into court action to obtain their rights.

The effect of the application of the bill is that if it is passed it will apply to rebate applications not yet determined at the time the bill receives the royal assent. Rebate applications that are before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and not yet determined by the tribunal will be subject to the provisions of the bill. So while the past rebate claims of some entities which have already been paid will not have to be disgorged under the provisions of this bill, any claims that have not yet been paid or are the subject of an appeal before the courts or the AAT will be denied by the bill.

PARA.TAB: That will remove the entitlement to the rebate from some companies and individuals and not from others on a totally arbitrary and therefore unjust basis. It is worse than arbitrary, because it is within the power of the government to not determine an application and thereby subject it to the retrospective operation of the bill.

As I read subsection 5(iv) of the bill, it presents the extraordinary situation that an applicant for a rebate could have had it denied and then argued a case before the AAT and lost, argued it before the Federal Court of Australia and lost, and then appealed to the High Court of Australia. After argument had been completed there and the decision reserved, the applicant could find that the law had changed under his feet.

It is even worse than that. He could have succeeded before the AAT and the Federal Court. He could have then been the subject of an appeal to the High Court where the case is argued on an appeal brought by the Commonwealth, and, because the Commonwealth is appealing, the retrospectivity will bite.

Between now and 1 July, the Commonwealth can effectively deny entitlement to anybody who has a case before the tribunals or courts by simply lodging an appeal against a decision against the Commonwealth. That is arbitrary, if ever anything was. In the context of a revenue raising measure it is totally extraordinary. I am, frankly, dumbfounded by the simplistic justification that the government offers. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay) has effectively explained that the retrospective operation is specifically designed to defeat litigation—currently before the courts—which the government expects to lose.

Another facet of the foolishness of retrospective legislation is demonstrated by this bill. As the Business Council of Australia pointed out on Monday, 5 June 1995, by using retrospective legislation to overturn a law that has been in place for nearly a decade, the federal government will only send the wrong signal to both domestic and foreign investors in Australia about Australia's position as a nation with low sovereign risk.

As a technique, the retrospectivity which this bill seeks to put in place is totally objectionable. If a department or a government does not like an interpretation by a court or does not accept the need to change the legislation prospectively, but wants to change it administratively, this bill presents it with the opportunity of doing so, simply by enabling it to deny an application for a privilege, concession or rebate. It can do that in the face of the law and then, by using numbers, it can seek to change the law retrospectively. One can only hope that the Senate has more sense.

The imposition of the retrospective operation of this particular piece of legislation is so ham-fisted it begs belief. It is made worse because it has an arbitrary operation. The government has appealed to what an ordinary person would think. In my opinion, no right thinking person could support the retrospective operation of this proposed legislation, no matter how much the person supported the substance of the change.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank the contribution of honourable members to the debate, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) and, of course, the last speaker, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams). Each of the speakers has dealt with the matter of litigation and the issue of retrospectivity. The explanatory memorandum makes it quite clear that the payment of rebate on diesel fuel was originally intended by the Fraser government to be made to those persons who are involved in the mainstream of mining as understood by the common person. This intention is explicit in the terms of paragraph 164(1)(a) of the Customs Act which provides eligibility for the payment of rebate in respect of diesel fuel for use in mining operations. It then goes on to deal with a further explanation of that description.

PARA.TAB: Since the introduction of the scheme in 1982, 168 cases have been litigated before the AAT and finalised. Some of the cases progressed to the Federal Court on appeal; 95 cases have been litigated since 1990. A small proportion of cases dealt with the core definitions of mining operations or primary production, but the majority of challenges were in respect of the interpretation of the sweeper clauses and the definitions of mining operations and agriculture which allow rebate to be paid on diesel fuel used to carry out operations that are connected with mining or agriculture.

Generally speaking, claimants under the sweeper clauses are themselves not miners, or primary producers, but are service or transport contractors, referred to during the speech by the honourable member for Gippsland, providers of utilities, government or semi-government enterprises such as—

EMPHASIS.TAB: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.05 p.m. to 1.19 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension, I was saying that, generally speaking, claimants under the sweeper clauses are service or transport contractors. But this is not to say that they are never miners or farmers: clearly, many of them are. But, in respect of sweeper clauses, the Federal Court has stated that, for an activity to be connected with agriculture or mining, the connection must be sufficient, more than tenuous. The court has also said that one thing must be bound up with another, that a connection must be real and substantial. That has been the law, as it has been understood, for a long period.

PARA.TAB: In the recent case of Cowell Electric Supply Co., the Federal Court has abandoned these tests and has said that one can look at spatial, temporal, economic and mechanical factors and that the set of factors which bears upon the issue is open. The question of what is connected with this has become so subjective that it is almost like asking how long a piece of string is. This makes determining eligibility for diesel fuel rebate difficult for administrators and presents a real risk of inconsistency. It can be unfair to claimants because they cannot plan their financial affairs with any degree of certainty and, indeed, substantial resources are spent in trying to obtain such certainty and in trying to second-guess the AAT or the Federal Court on these issues, where there is little consensus between Customs and the claimants.

Let me deal with this issue on the question of time. In the city of Nunawading case referred to by the member for Gippsland, there was a decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in September 1994. As I am informed, that was the first successful appeal in that area. There are 967 notices of intention currently held. They present no cost to the claimants except the cost of postage. For example, the Neumann Sands case was an Administrative Appeals Tribunal case in February 1995. The Water Authority of Western Australia case was 30 May 1995 and the case of the Cowell Electric Supply Co. was a decision of the Full Court of the Federal Court in January 1995. This legislation has been in effect since 1982 so these decisions which have given rise to these concerns are very recent.

One issue was raised by the member for Tangney and I must address it in the short time available to me. I say it is incorrect to suggest that the issue of retrospectivity will deny a successful appellant or claimant before the AAT that to which it is entitled in terms of money. Where a claimant has succeeded before the AAT, it has a right to be paid. That has occurred in the definition of mining for minerals and in the sweeper claims. That is a judgment in favour of the applicant entitled to payment, and that has occurred following each AAT judgment. Again, there are other examples in that regard. So where a claimant has succeeded, that claim will be paid. I have explained in my second reading speech that these other prospective claims will no longer now be open to those particular claimants.

In my second reading speech, I have summarised quite clearly the main features of the bill. Apart from the issues that I have addressed in my summing up, I do not believe that anything raised by the opposition warrants further comment. Accordingly, I commend the bill to the Committee without amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Lindsay)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY BILL 1995Cognate bills:AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK (QUOTAS) AMENDMENT BILL 1995MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY LEGISLATION REPEAL BILL 1995BEEF PRODUCTION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1995LIVE-STOCK EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1995LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1995CATTLE TRANSACTION LEVY BILL 1995CATTLE EXPORT CHARGES AMENDMENT BILL 1995NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY ADMINISTRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (CATTLE EXPORT) LEVY BILL 1995NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (CATTLE TRANSACTIONS) LEVY BILL 1995NATIONAL CATTLE DISEASE ERADICATION TRUST ACCOUNT AMENDMENT BILL 1995PRIMARY INDUSTRIES LEVIES AND CHARGES COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1995EXOTIC ANIMAL DISEASE CONTROL AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 29 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Meat and Live-stock Industry Bill 1995 and associated bills form part of a package of legislation to reform the meat and livestock industry statutory arrangements. The Meat and Live-stock Industry Bill 1995 is the main bill dealing with the reforms. The other bills associated with this package give effect to the arrangements by providing funding for the statutory bodies, for transitional arrangements, as well as correcting and modernising the legal drafting of earlier legislation.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Meat and Live-stock Industry Bill 1995 and associated bills is to provide a statutory framework that will take the meat and livestock industry towards the next decade and beyond on a much stronger, coherent and commercially driven basis. The new arrangements provide industry with much greater responsibility for its own affairs, moves it towards a less government regulated environment and with statutory structures that are appropriate to the future commercial and consumer challenges. The current legislation has been in place since 1984 and has been successful in transforming industry from a production driven system to one which pays closer attention to consumer requirements.

With the assistance of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) and the Meat Research Corporation (MRC) industry has: put in place the means to convey market signals back to producers and computer driven marketing technology; focused on the expanding opportunities that have prevailed in north Asia; expanded the lot feed cattle industry to produce to exacting export market specifications; and recognised the importance of quality assurance.

But the pace of change has been slow and there is still considerable way to go in addressing increasing consumer expectations on food safety, becoming more cost competitive in meat processing and developing and implementing quality assurance systems.

Industry must take the leadership role on these issues and be responsible for the outcomes. Commercial judgment and responsibility is needed to meet the competitive challenges that lie ahead. I am confident that industry has the necessary leadership capability and that the new structures in this legislation will play the appropriate part in driving change and development.

There should be no commercial role, and I stress commercial role, for government in future arrangements. The role for government agencies is to facilitate industry development and to ensure the services it provides are cost effective and responsive to industry needs.

Let me be clear here, that this new direction in no way diminishes the important and active role which federal and state governments must play in ensuring health safety for consumers both here in australia and in our overseas markets.

This legislation is therefore necessary to assist industry move forward to its goal of becoming more internationally competitive and better able to respond to the more exacting consumer requirements now being demanded throughout the world. The new structure will better equip industry to make decisions and develop strategies that will allow it to take advantage of the expanded opportunities following the successful conclusion to the Uruguay GATT round. The new structural arrangements also assist industry through strategic planning to position itself better for the increased competition that is expected to come from foot-and-mouth free South American suppliers in the not too distant future. Domestic issues such as quality assurance, food safety and brand promotion will also benefit from a strategic approach under the new arrangements.

The new statutory arrangements have resulted from extensive consultation with industry during and following the Industry Commission inquiry into meat processing. Following the Industry Commission inquiry, a consultative process undertaken by the former chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council, Mr Bob McCarthy, generated a large measure of consensus within the industry on the need for reform as well as momentum and commitment to change throughout the industry.
The arrangements developed from the consultations and now embodied in the legislation have the full support of the key levy paying sectors of industry.

As implied earlier, the principle behind the reforms is to phase the government out of the statutory arrangements, through a staged approach of transferring greater responsibility for industry decision making to the industry itself, and eventually moving to a non-statutory environment.
The new Meat Industry Council (MIC) has the clear responsibility for developing the vision and strategic directions for the industry and for formulating broad industry policy.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.29 p.m. to 1.40 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The AMLC and MRC will be required to develop their corporate plans within the strategic framework developed by the MIC, and have the corporate plans approved by the MIC before seeking the minister's approval.

PARA.TAB: Importantly the MIC will be funded from a separate component of the industry levies and charges but this will not involve any levy increase on industry under current levy arrangements. Bills that give effect to this change include the Beef Production Levy Amendment Bill 1995, Cattle Export Charges Amendment Bill 1995, Cattle Transaction Levy Bill 1995, Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1995 and Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1995.

The MIC will operate with a small staff and budget, and staff will be managed by a highly qualified chief executive officer. Honourable members will be aware that Mr Geoff Jureidini has been appointed to the position by the interim Meat Industry Council. The MIC will be responsible for:

SPEECH.PARA: .developing the vision and strategic directions for the industry;
.formulating broad industry policy;
.approving the strategic plan of the AMLC and MRC;
.developing motions to be put to industry annual general meetings and special general meetings to provide funding for MIC, the AMLC and MRC;
.evaluating the performance of industry programs,
.developing proposals for industry self-regulation;
.developing a united industry approach to issues affecting the industry.

PARA.TAB: The legislation provides a sunset to the statutory structures at 30 June 1998. It is also the government's intention that there be a review by government and industry to commence no later than 1 July 1997. There has been a twofold purpose: to allow a staged management of the evolution of the arrangements, in light of concerns that the industry may need to develop further professionalism in some areas before taking on full responsibility; and to provide an incentive to ensure industry makes the MIC work, and to provide some certainty of movement towards the desired end point.

An interim MIC, operating under the existing AMLIPC legislation, has already met under Chairman-designate Robin Bligh and commenced the important task of developing the council's agenda and a strategic plan for the future. It has been very important that the MIC commence its operation on an interim basis before legislation is enacted to ensure that the momentum for change is not lost and that strategic planning commence to guide the corporations' activities.

The interim MIC mirrors the legislation and consists of industry leaders nominated by the industry organisations as agreed with the peak industry levy-paying bodies. In addition to the 12 producers, processors and exporters nominated by the Cattle Council of Australia, Sheepmeats Council of Australia, Australian Meat Council, Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia, have been added a representative of the Australian Lot Feeders Association, the Australian Livestock Exporters Association, the Australian Supermarket Institute Limited, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and a government member.

The additional organisations reflect their importance in the meat and livestock industry and they will no doubt add to the quality of the decision making by that body. Although the chairpersons of the AMLC and MRC will not be members of the MIC, as appropriate, they can be invited to attend council meetings. The composition of the MIC is quite large but this provides industry `ownership' and the confidence that their views are being represented in the important strategic planning and policy developments for the industry.

Members of the MIC will be part time and appointed for up to three years at a time, although organisations may request replacement of one or more of their representatives at any time. There is no provision for deputies of members to ensure that continuity is given importance and that members and organisations take their responsibilities seriously. The legislation also provides for remuneration of members of the MIC—not to cover loss of income specifically, but to further encourage members' commitment to the council. Such remuneration will be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal.

For the MIC to work effectively, there must be a clear acceptance by industry organisations and all members of council of their leadership role for the wider industry and not specific sectoral interests. It is also very important for representatives of council being able to make decisions for industry with authority. The government expects that the MIC will not be involved in the day-to-day program management of the corporations. Although the MIC will have a broad control over the AMLC and MRC budgets, it will not have a mandate to involve itself in program delivery, nor will it be involved in line-by-line examination of the corporations' budgets. The council will set the strategic directions against which programs will be developed, approve the strategic plans of the corporations and recommend appropriate levy rates to fund those plans.

The MIC is tasked with working with the government and industry to develop the next steps to move to a non-statutory environment, developing directions for industry self-regulation and assisting the AMLC to develop timetables for the commercialisation of programs which will be best managed in a commercial environment. The MIC has an important role in the evaluation of industry programs managed by the corporations. Given the difficulties involved in quantifying the benefits of marketing and research activities, and in circumstances where there is little information available to levy payers and government to judge the performance of the AMLC and MRC, it will be an important role for the MIC to provide independent information to levy payers on the effectiveness of programs against predetermined performance criteria.

Such evaluation measures should be objective indicators which are monitored and reported on a regular basis. The MIC can also provide detailed case studies on the costs and benefits of specific programs of each organisation—or monitor the progress of the AMLC and MRC in fulfilling predetermined deadlines, such as the commercialisation of programs. Overall, an evaluation role will increase the transparency of the AMLC's and MRC's operations, as well as placing pressure on both organisations to continually improve performance.

The MIC will be responsible for providing funding to the peak industry councils for consultations with the AMLC and MRC, unlike the present arrangement where the corporations provide such funding. It is appropriate that in determining the overall levels of funding, that industry also be responsible for determining consultation funding. However, the MIC and recipient bodies will be required to meet the government's guidelines concerning consultation funding and the recipient bodies will also be required to provide the minister with audited financial statements in relation to the funding.

Industry has been concerned for some time about the cost and substance of AGMs of the corporations. It is however necessary for the purposes of accountability to both the government and levy payers that AGMs continue. In the corporate world there is direct accountability to shareholders by private companies through an AGM process. As there will now be a staged move towards a non-statutory environment, it is important that such accountability mechanisms are not removed which would subsequently need to be reintroduced in a corporate environment.

Under the legislation, a new approach will take place at future AGMs. The MIC will be required to convene an annual industry conference, open to all registered levy and charge payers. However, it will be a `forward looking' process that will enable industry to consider the broad strategic directions for industry and provide a forum for discussion of important industry issues, unlike the current AGMs which by their very nature are retrospective.

AGMs will, however, be a smaller subset of the conference. The MIC will convene an industry annual general meeting of the three statutory bodies to formally present their annual reports, vote on any levy and charge motions put forward by the council, and vote on any no confidence motions put forward by levy and charge payers. This is necessary to provide accountability to the wider industry shareholders. All levy motions will be put forward by the MIC. Under the current arrangements the AMLC and MRC put forward their own motions to separate annual general meetings.

There is also a provision for the MIC to convene a special general meeting to consider a change in levy rates for the MIC, AMLC and MRC to meet special circumstances. This is not intended to be a regularly used power, but should be a safeguard to allow the industry to raise funds quickly to deal with an urgent industry management problem. The MIC will also be required to produce an annual report to parliament which must include the results of evaluations undertaken of AMLC and MRC programs.

During the industry consultations there has been clear industry support for the thrust of the IC recommendations dealing with the commercialisation of some AMLC programs. Industry had in mind particularly the computer-assisted livestock marketing program, commonly referred to as CALM, and Aus-Meat programs, but there may be other programs which industry might determine can better operate in a commercial environment.

The new legislation assists with the commercialisation of schemes such as the CALM program and Aus-Meat, a product description and quality assurance program under the strategic guidance of the MIC. The legislation allows AMLC, in cooperation with another organisation, to facilitate the marketing of goods other than meat and livestock. This will allow other species to participate in CALM to improve its commercial viability and allow AMLC to entice private equity into this program. However, eligible schemes will need to be prescribed, and details of the scope of their operations will need to be set out in the AMLC's corporate plan, which requires ministerial approval and the agreement of the MIC.

The AMLC's legislation will also be extended to cover by-products of the meat and livestock industry. This is a power which the MRC already has under its legislation. Given the need for industry to become more competitive, it is important that every opportunity be taken by industry to add value. In this regard, it will be up to the MIC to develop a strategy for adding value in the by-products and co-products areas, where there is considerable scope for further improvement. The legislation provides the MIC with the option, if it so chooses, of using the AMLC, as well as the MRC, as the program delivery mechanism under any agreed industry strategy.

There are some functions and powers which are removed from the AMLC legislation and these include: the funding of industry bodies for consultation purposes, which will be transferred to the MIC, as mentioned earlier; the power to trade in meat and livestock; and the power to set conditions on the shipping of meat and livestock from Australia. Industry supports the removal of AMLC shipping and trading powers. These provisions are against the thrust of government's deregulatory reform, are not currently in use or likely to be used in the future. The MIC will examine the AMLC licensing powers and the implications for Aus-Meat and quota controls. In the interim, the AMLC will continue to administer export quota schemes where they become necessary on the basis determined by the MIC under the strategic planning process.

The AMLC legislation is being amended to ensure that the MIC has a full range of options that it can consider when developing the policy framework for quota administration. The legislation includes provisions that will permit the allocation of quota free of charge or by auction, sale by tender or private sale. The Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Amendment Bill 1995 gives effect to this provision. It is important that the MIC is not constrained in its analysis of options by legislation that predicates only one option—and that is, the status quo of allocation of quota free of charge.

Board membership for both the AMLC and MRC will be reduced from 11 to seven members to reflect their more sharply focused program management role. The boards will consist of: a chairperson, chosen and appointed by the minister; a managing director, chosen and appointed by the corporation; a government member, chosen and appointed by the minister; and four other members, appointed by the minister from candidates selected by a selection committee against a set of skills-based selection criteria. All members, apart from the managing director, will be part-time.

The membership of the AMLC and MRC (except the chairs and managing directors) are to become vacant on the commencement of the amendments to the legislation. This is necessary administratively given the legislative requirement that qualifications and experience must collectively be achieved by the selection process. In addition, the legislative sunset provision prevents the phase-in of new board members appointed for a normal three-year period as the terms of current board members expire.

Although current board appointments will continue until 30 June 1995, I want to take this opportunity to thank the current board members for their work up to that period and place on record that this necessary action is no reflection on their performance. I also want to take this opportunity to thank the chair of the AMLC, John Kerin, and of the MRC, Robin Bligh, for their stewardship of the corporations at what has been an unsettling period for industry.

The AMLC board members will need to collectively possess qualifications and experience in the following fields of activity: livestock production; the processing and export of meat; business management; finance and industrial relations; the promotion of products; and the international marketing of products. MRC board members will need to possess qualifications and experience in the following fields of activity: livestock production; the processing and export of meat; business management and finance; administration of research and development; commercialisation of the results of research and development; and conservation and management of natural resources and environmental and ecological matters.

The criteria for board selections for the corporations encompass qualifications and experience that are necessary for effective decision taking and effective delivery of MIC strategies. Effective delivery of MIC strategies also requires that AMLC and MRC board members possess an ability to understand strategic plans and how programs can be developed to achieve those plans.

An opportunity has also been taken in the legislation to streamline selection committee arrangements. Whilst it is accepted that previous selection committees have done an excellent job with their selections, there is now no real need for a seven-person selection committee to represent industry, particularly since the strategic planning, policy development and industry funding decisions are to be taken by the Meat Industry Council.

For the success of future arrangements, it is very important that broad strategic planning and policy decisions are taken in the MIC and not in the corporation boards, and that the boards are skills based for their program delivery role. The selection committee is therefore reduced from seven members to four and moves away from the specific representative approach under current legislation. The new legislation provides for a four-person selection committee with an independent chair appointed by the minister and three members on the nomination of the MIC, which the minister would also appoint.

A selection committee has been convened to begin the task of selecting members for the AMLC and MRC boards. Ms Julia King has been appointed as presiding member and she will be ably assisted in the selection process by three members nominated by the interim Meat Industry Council. It is appropriate that the selection process be undertaken on the basis which is to be followed under the new legislation.

In the legislation the government will take the opportunity to correct a previous legislative drafting error with respect to the cattle transaction levy (CTL), cattle export charge (CEC), and national residue survey (NRS) cattle acts which imposed a customs duty and an excise duty in the same acts. These acts will need to be amended and the levies and charges reimposed retrospectively. However, payments made under the old acts will satisfy any retrospective obligations imposed by the new acts. The Cattle Transaction Levy Bill 1995, Cattle Export Charges Amendment Bill 1995, National Residue Survey (Cattle Export) Levy Bill 1995, National Residue Survey Administration Amendment Bill 1995, National Residue Survey (Cattle Transactions) Levy Bill 1995 and Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1995 give effect to this amendment. If not, we will get some more bills!

Honourable members will recall that the levy imposed by the Cattle Transaction Levy Act 1990 has been an integral part of a package of arrangements for (red) meat and livestock industry levies and charges developed by the industry itself. It has been successful in providing a more visible and equitable division of levy and charge payments between industry sectors by clarifying the relative contributions paid by each sector.

The Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Repeal Bill 1995 repeals current legislation and provides transitional provisions relating to AMLC's export licences, keeping of registers, export quotas, enforcement, EEO programs, and both AMLC's and MRC's membership and staff, and 1994-95 annual reports, as well as payments of money and ministerial directions to AMLC and MRC.

The National Cattle Disease Eradication Trust Account Amendment Bill 1995 validates the payment of amounts of money equal to the national cattle eradication trust account components of levies and charges into the trust account. This is necessary to overcome an oversight in the original act.

The Exotic Animal Disease Control Amendment Bill 1989 is a consequential amendment arising from the repeal of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 and the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985, and their replacement by the Meat and Live-stock Industry Bill 1995. This bill enables any money remaining in the EXANDIS trust account after the sunset date of 30 June 1995 to be returned to the relevant contributing bodies, including the AMLC and the MRC.

Opportunity is also taken in this legislation to take the buffalo industry out from the umbrella of the AMLC and the MRC. The buffalo industry, which is a relatively small industry, believes that the Rural Industry Research and Development Corporation (RIRDC) is better placed to meet its needs. The Livestock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1995 and Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1995 provide the mechanism for diverting levy funds being paid by the buffalo industry from the AMLC and the MRC to RIRDC.

There are two other issues identified by the IC inquiry into meat processing which impact on the meat and livestock industry and its ability to become more competitive—industrial relations and the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. These two issues are being pursued by the government under separate processes and are not the subject of the reforms under this legislation. I propose therefore only to make a few observations.
Honourable members would be aware that in regard to both matters progress is being made. The Industrial Relations Act provides an effective framework for progressing industrial relations issues—

TALK.START.PARA: —Think about it. I'll talk about that in a minute.

—I am sure the honourable member will do so. The parties to that are commencing to use it with more frequency. So it is going all right. To date some 34 enterprise agreements have been certified by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. A national industry consultative council has now been established under the auspices of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and will facilitate and encourage the parties to work together in resolving industrial relations difficulties. The government has been reforming the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service over the past two years and is firmly committed to continuing this process.

PARA.TAB: The legislative changes are about industry facing up to and being responsible for their own actions through self-regulation. But the government has no intention of walking away from the industry as it pursues this course. Industry and government can and will work together in a cooperative relationship to meet the commercial challenges ahead—one that recognises the importance of an industry leadership role and of commercial judgment and responsibility. Industry has the necessary leadership capability and will have the benefit of the new statutory arrangements to drive the changes that are required.
I commend these bills to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to see who now files into the place. We will have some predictable debates on these meat bills along the lines that they have gone before. I just wonder how many people in this room and out and beyond realise—probably you do, Mr Deputy Speaker—what an absolute farce we are witnessing in this chamber in many real ways right now.

PARA.TAB: The legislation before us is a wholly inadequate response to major recommendations made 14 or 15 months ago about the competitiveness of Australia's major agricultural export industry, in a report which said that major and sweeping reforms were needed—a report which has been largely shoved under the carpet. I will come later to some of the claims in the set speech made a few moments ago by the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall). Here we are debating that report, at a time when the industry is in very serious competitive difficulties, in the second chamber of this House and at a time when the responsible minister, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), is not even in the country.

Whilst we hear all of this talk around the place about vision statements for Australia and about how we are going to take up our place in Asia and how we are matching world best practice and all the rest of it, in this chamber we are seeing the reality of the government's refusal to tackle the hard issues that are of critical importance if we are to take our place in global trading terms and, I believe, in terms of our economic and social freedom in the longer term. I do not use those terms lightly.

I am going to illustrate this in a way which will undoubtedly make the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) utter some remark about how I have said it all before. But in the sense that she belongs to a team that has not addressed any of these issues, I indicate to her that I am going to continue to use this example until some effective reforms are put in place.

Honourable members would recall that towards the end of last year a well-known Australian restaurant chain went to import 12 or 13 container loads of American rump. The chain claimed that that had to do with the drought, but under public pressure it backed off and said, `No, we will continue sourcing the product in Australia,' so obviously the product supply was not the problem that it had initially made out. That particular chain buys on price, amongst other things, and I do not in any way criticise it for that. It has a long record of doing so and sees no reason why it should change now, and there is no reason why I would suggest that it should change.

So we went and had a look at the question of price. We found that people who wanted to import beef from America could go to that country, where they would pay a great deal more for the raw product than they would in Australia. The American producer, in other words, gets a better return than the Australian producer. Those purchasers would put the beef through an American packing house, or an abattoir, in our language, and pack it into boxes, into containers; they would truck it to the seaboard and across an American wharf; then they would ship it across the Pacific and unload it across our wharves—so well reformed by the current Minister for Primary Industries and Energy when he was the minister responsible for waterfront reform that they only cost two or three times as much now as wharves across the Tasman—and past our DPIE arrangements, protocols and what have you; and that American steak could be distributed in this country for around $5.80 a kilo. The best one can source the Australian product for is around $6.20.

I bowled a question up to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It bears repeating. I am bored with telling the story but I am going to keep telling it. I asked, `Prime Minister, how is this so? Does it not indicate that your charges and your taxes on the meat industry and your industrial relations approaches are making us non-competitive? If we cannot compete here at home on our own domestic markets as the world's major exporter of beef, how are we ever going to make it in Asia if this is indicative of the lack of real reform in this country?' The Prime Minister, as Hansard will confirm, in effect said to me, `Well, aren't you a mug for highlighting the inefficiency of the Australian beef producer?' That is what he said. The mob opposite ought to be absolutely ashamed of that response and the Prime Minister ought to take a little more notice of his own people, the people who in this country advise the government on industry progress, on industry's needs for reform, on how our industries need to be updated to be internationally competitive.

It would have been better if the Prime Minister actually had sought to be honest and had displayed a little more integrity in this process. I must say that I am very sad that a lot of the commentators that day refused to pick it up, as well. I pursued it with quite a few people in the media. I said, `Look, this is about the drought, it is about industrial relations, it is about trade, it is about agriculture, our place in Asia, taxes, charges—the whole gamut.' It really is indicative of what is wrong right across the board, why we believe that radical change is necessary in this country in terms of our cultural attitudes, in terms of the way we work together, in terms of the way we stop short-term expediency in taxation formation at the expense all the time of long-term gain for the Australian community. Yet none of the media covered it.

Anyway, here it is, the Industry Commission report, the government's own, which came out in April last year—very comprehensive; this is only a fraction of it. It is the latest in quite a long line—I have got some more here and I will refer to that in a moment—which condemn the lack of efficiency and reform in the Australian meat industry and first of all gives the lie to the Prime Minister's claims and the nonsense we will hear later from one or two opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: Now listen to this, from the introduction to the overview. The second paragraph states:

With abundant grazing land and a favourable climate, Australia produces livestock at very low cost by international standards. However, efficient processing is necessary if we are to take full advantage of our comparative advantage in livestock production.
Although Australian meat is generally price competitive on export markets—
I wish the Prime Minister was listening—
this is largely because processors are able to buy livestock at very low prices compared with processors of other countries.

This inquiry has found that despite some recent improvements, Australia's meat processing industry operates at significantly higher cost than processing industries of most countries with which it competes. It has also found that Australian meat exports have been losing market share in almost all of our major export markets.

So let us put furphy No. 1 to rest. The Australian producer is not inefficient. He is amongst the world's most efficient, if not the most efficient, particularly in terms of manpower. There can be no suggestion that that is not so, when he is able to survive—and that is all he is doing at the moment—on returns some 50 or 60 per cent less than his American counterpart gets, and continues to produce and continues to undergird Australia as the most significant exporter of beef globally at the moment. He cannot possibly be inefficient. He has had to be efficient to survive. The people who represent beef industries, cattlemen, ought to go out there and explain to their people that the Prime Minister does not know what he is talking about. His gratuitously insulting remarks about the efficiency of the Australian beef producer ought to be exposed for what they are.

PARA.TAB: I want to continue to read some of this in. I mean, this is the government's report, this is what government members are responding to—with the minister not even in the country, in the second chamber in the House—15 months after the government's own report indicates major change is necessary. The third heading is `Towards a new productive culture' and the report goes on to say, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: But change has been painfully slow. To seize the opportunities now being presented, the industry must significantly accelerate the changes taking place.

Labour is by far the largest single input cost of processing livestock into meat. The industry has been disadvantaged by a poor industrial relations climate and a poor occupational health and safety record. Features of the industry's awards system inhibit innovation and have contributed to industrial unrest. Seniority systems and daily hire provide insufficient incentives for training and skills development. The complexity of the tally system, and its structure of premium rates of remuneration for extra output, reduces incentive for improving working conditions and productivity.
Capacity utilisation of the Australian industry is lower than that of our competitors, resulting in higher fixed costs per unit of output. Where seasonality dominates production—
and that is a problem in Australia—
and livestock must travel long distances to slaughter, low levels of capital utilisation in some regions may be, to some extent, beyond our control.

Now the Meat Research Corporation acknowledges that point as well, but goes on to make out that it can only account for a percentage of our relative cost disadvantage in this country. The IC report goes on to say:
But poor capital utilisation is also directly attributable to inflexibilities associated with industrial awards—
we heard this nonsense, so I will get on to this in a minute, about how much reform has taken place in recent times, and we have got some very interesting stuff for the people opposite—

particularly penalty rates which rise with increased hours of operation and multiple shifts. The Commission has found that greater flexibility—particularly greater use of enterprise agreements—could bring about significant productivity gains . . .

Here is the rub, here is the bit that gets under my skin so much from people opposite who say that we are about driving down conditions, award arrangements and so forth for workers. Their future is dependent on reform in this industry, and the IC says it. The next words are:
with benefits for workers—
they put them first—
producers, processors, and some consumers.

It is about time some of the people in this place who purport to represent the interests of workers realise that some genuine reform is the only way their jobs, and the jobs of their kids, in so much of rural Australia are still going to be there in the future. The report continues:

The evidence available to the Commission indicates that there are gains to be realised from reform. While the magnitude of the estimated gains varies between studies, reductions in processing costs of at least 8 to 10 per cent are achievable though they could be significantly higher.

An extra eight to 10 per cent is pretty minor stuff compared to what all the other reports say is available. Those gains would be worth hundreds of millions of dollars to the Queensland economy and to the Queensland beef industry—let alone to everywhere else in the country. Some of that money could be usefully directed to the workers in the industry who, in my opinion, are underpaid for doing a very tough job. I would be the first to say that they are entitled to a fairer go, but they will not get it until they are allowed freely to enter into arrangements—and I use that word advisedly—which will benefit all. That will require better performance from employers as well as from employees, but particularly it will mean some major changes in attitudes and behavioural patterns on the part of our trade unions.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer also to the Meat Research Corporation report. That is the really interesting one. That report established, in a comparison of Australia, America and Argentina, that we were far and away the most inefficient. So, perhaps being generous, it thought it should see whether it could find somebody else that Australia could outdo. So it had a look at Ireland and New Zealand as well and guess what? Instead of being at the bottom of a pile of three we came at the bottom of a pile of five. Nothing has changed since then.

The report indicated that the labour component in the processing of beef in America is as low as 13 1/2c per kilo, that in New Zealand it is about 25c—remember that only a few years ago it was at our sorts of levels—and that the Argentineans are about to manage that sort of performance as well. In Australia as recently as a couple of years ago our best practice was obstinately stuck at the high 40c level—three times the American level. That is hardly a Third World country level, hardly a country where slave labour rates are paid, despite what the members opposite are saying. We saw that furphy well and truly closed off yesterday in the House. The reality is that we have failed to develop our efficiencies and our productive capabilities, and we have failed to develop a sense of mutuality and commonsense in the development of a way forward for the industry so that we are woefully off the pace. Not only the future of producers is at risk but also the future of workers in the industry, as the Industry Commission report itself said. Booz Allen made the point that New Zealand has demonstrated conclusively that change is possible. It went on to say that these issues must be addressed, that a great deal more needs to be done, and that the price of continuing failure to reform will be very high indeed.

I want to make a couple of other points that are highly relevant. Again, the government has taken 14 or 15 slovenly months to respond to these issues—something should have been put in place 10 years ago—but finally the government has got around to a response. The world has moved on while precious little has happened in this country.

It was not long ago that we were worried about the enormous pile of frozen beef in Europe and we were concerned that that might be used to flood our markets. We were all very relieved when the GATT signatories arrived and it was presumed that we need not worry about the breaking of the Andriessen agreement under which the Europeans would not move their beef product in store onto our markets.

However, we still have a major problem with the beef stockpile which this time is going to affect us. While we have sat on our hands and done nothing, the European stockpile has largely disappeared but there is another one: 600,000 tonnes of beef surplus to requirements are sloshing around in the US looking for a home. We could condemn the Americans for their ridiculous subsidy packages which have resulted in that surplus but we at home might have been doing something to ensure that we would be able to compete with that beef, given the pressures it is going to put on our markets.

The situation is made worse: Uruguay has recently completed its OIE obligations. I cannot pronounce the words that OIE stands for but basically it is the World Trade Organisation's exotic diseases headquarters. Uruguay has just completed the requirements there so it will now be allowed to ship fresh meats to the US from 1 July this year. From the year's end, on a zonal basis Argentina will also be free to ship meat into the USA, traditionally our most important market and one we have virtually lost now. What is it going to mean? Will it mean ever more products sloshing around on world markets at a time when we are less able than ever to compete fully?

I come next to the actual bill. I want to say a few things specifically about it as far as it goes. Broadly, we will support the Meat Industry Council although, to be honest, I have some real reservations even about it. I will support it because the industry said it wants it and because the alternatives that were put before the industry were even less attractive. But I want to make some points about it. There are 23 IC recommendations. I will not read them all in; if I had time, I would.

There are 23 recommendations to the government in this: three deal directly with industrial relations reforms; seven deal with the AMLC; seven deal with actions which the government should undertake in relation to market access and the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service; one deals with local government; one concerns licensing; one is about R&D; one recommends the restructuring of the policy council—this legislation; and one suggests the policy council investigate the scope of the AMLC to fund individual projects by way of direct charges to beneficiaries and concomitant reductions in general levies. In relation to the recommendation on a restructured policy council, the Industry Commission said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission considers that the AMLIPC—
the policy council—

should be restructured, that its membership should more directly reflect the views of levy payers and major stakeholders such as employees, with government and quasi-public bodies currently represented, such as AQIS, AMLC and MRC, as non-voting members.
Restructured in such a way, the AMLIPC would be able to play a valuable role in setting major policy priorities for the industry on an ongoing basis.
That would be fine if it were really free to enact them. It continued:
