Recommendations made by the Commission on the scope for project financing in the AMLC and the possible introduction of multiple export inspection standards should be considered by the AMLIPC, as could issues such as the benefits of an industry-wide system for grading of Australian meat sold in domestic and international markets. A restructured AMLIPC could also be responsible for undertaking external evaluation of the effectiveness of AMLC and MRC programs.

So this legislation will supposedly establish new arrangements which are intended to give industry a greater role and more responsibility in deciding its own affairs, and move it to a less regulated environment. Broadly speaking, I have no objection to that. The problem is, of course, that it is not going to be able to do it in terms of the existing regimes, the existing obstacles to reform and the existing cost structures.

PARA.TAB: The Meat and Live-stock Industry Bill, the main bill in the package, establishes a new council—the Meat Industry Council—to replace the old policy council. It redefines the role of the AMLC and the MRC. The new council will be responsible for developing strategic industry policy which will then provide the framework under which the AMLC and the MRC will develop their corporate and operations plans. The bill is transitional. It is to start on 1 July this year and will sunset on 30 June 1998. At that stage it is intended that the three statutory industry authorities will revert to a non-statutory status.

I do not know how that is going to work. What do we do if we have to impose, say, export restrictions or quotas or whatever on countries which will only take limited amounts of our product? We do not assume we are going to be in a totally free-trading world environment by then. I do not know how we are going to do it without a statutory authority. However, there is the capacity to review this after a couple of years. I can assure members that if there is a change of government it will be reviewed long before then. The government says it will also enable the industry to identify its problems and to devise commercial responses to them. As I have said before, in terms of the government's legislative roadblocks to that sort of process, in my view it just is not going to happen.

The MIC will also be responsible for funding of the AMLC and the MRC through the power to recommend levy rates to industry annual general meetings. This will ensure that programs of the AMLC and the MRC conform with the industry's strategic direction laid down by the MIC. The MIC will be accountable to the minister and to parliament and will have to produce a corporate plan and an annual report each year, projecting three years ahead. The corporations will only be accountable to the MIC. The MIC is to be a body corporate as it will be holding money on its own account and will have the ability to employ staff and consultants. It must hold an annual conference and organise annual general meetings of each statutory body during the conference. And at conference there will be discussion of broad industry concerns, but no motions of a general industry nature.

There will be 18 members of the MIC, comprising a chairman, a government member, both of whom will be appointed by the minister who will also appoint other members on the recommendation of the Cattle Council of Australia, the Sheepmeat Council of Australia, the Australian Meat Council, the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Australian Livestock Exporters Association, the Australian Lot Feeders Association, the Australian Supermarket Institute Ltd, and other members prescribed by regulation. Before appointment of a chairman, the minister must consult the above bodies, and a person employed by any of these bodies is not eligible for appointment.

I will not go on with the rest of the detail; that has been adequately outlined, in terms of the legislative changes anyway, by the minister who presented this stuff to us a little while ago. I want to revert to the real issues for the future of the meat industry which are things such as: government reform of its statutory authorities—including AQIS; costs and charges; and industrial relations. Let us start by debunking one interesting little claim made by the minister when he said—and he was just echoing something that Minister Collins said in Queensland a little while ago—that, `Golly, gee whiz, we have 34 enterprise agreements up and going.' One industry leader has told me in no uncertain terms that 16 of them constitute nothing more than an agreement by unions to talk in return for a wage increase. That is pretty indicative of what we seem to be talking about when the government comes to tell us about its improved industrial relations approach.

The minister went on to say that the current legislation provided good guidelines and good capacity for industrial relations reform. He said it could all happen under the government's package. That is an interesting claim. But it just happens that I have come across a review of progress in workplace reform in the export meat processing sector that was put together for none other than the department itself. It says some pretty interesting things. It was commissioned by the federal Department of Industrial Relations to review the progress of, and impediments to, workplace reform in the export meat processing sector. It is based on a series of interviews with chief executives of major companies in the industry, representatives of the ACTU, the industry's principal union, and representatives of other organisations with an interest in, or involvement with, the industry.
Specifically, they said some interesting things. For example:

SPEECH.PARA: Progress has generally been limited, with little to show in terms of widespread and quantifiable increases in productivity and efficiency. Where progress has been evident, enterprise bargaining has been a component of a broader program to improve culture and relationships across the companies' operations.
But then the report goes on to say, in reference to the general nature of enterprise bargains:
The enterprise bargains achieved to date have not been particularly innovative or successful in encouraging improvements at the plant level.
Can you believe it? It said:
In many cases, they have been little more than a means to achieve a general wage increase.

Here we are—with a critically important industry to this country's export performance. It may have escaped those opposite that we have a trade crisis in this country. We are a long way behind. When major reform is necessary and when we are facing massive and increasing competition abroad, what does this report say? It says that such modest reforms as the minister is able to refer to are virtually valueless. That is what this says. It says:

Virtually without exception, all parties have been critical of the lack of progress in addressing issues through the AIRC processes. Many companies now have little confidence in the system and believe that if a change is to be successful, then it will only be possible through action at the company level. While the parties have agreed to participate, there is little expectation at this stage that the newly formed Industry Consultative Council—
by which I take it they mean the MIC—

will achieve any concrete outcomes. It would be unfortunate, however, if the ICC was not supported, as it could be a useful forum to address industry-wide issues if the appropriate attitudes existed among the parties.
It goes on to say:
There would need to be quite dramatic changes in approach to convince many of the key players to participate constructively in any industry level initiatives.

This is not going to drive it, is it? It is just a cop-out, designed to put another buffer zone between the ministry and the government on the one hand, and industry and their needs for reform on the other—reform in the interests not just of the industry but of the workers who depend upon it for their jobs now and in the future.

PARA.TAB: I want to read into the record just a couple of other things out of this report. It identifies a number of impediments to workplace reform and I want to cover just two of them that relate to employers and unions—firstly, employers:

SPEECH.PARA: With some exceptions the industry's individual employers generally display a traditional and narrow approach to relations with their employees and unions and fail to acknowledge change where it has occurred. The concept of best practice is not well understood by the industry's employers, who have generally looked for excuses rather than accept that the initiative for reform must lie with management.
Fair cop, they have got to wear that criticism. It is all about industrial relations. The report continues:

(b) The union has adopted a narrow view of enterprise bargaining and has been reluctant to allow direct discussions between management and employees. There is a significant gap between the positive views expressed by national officials and the approach of officials at plant level. The union has not been active in educating the work force to the benefits of change and lacks capacity, resources and commitment to reform throughout its organisation.

The fact of the matter is that, in this country, until those who are responsible frame suitable legislation and practices that govern how we work and determine whether or not we will be forced to communicate with one another sensibly in our workplaces—where necessary, on a workplace by workplace basis—we will go nowhere.

PARA.TAB: Ms Henzell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Capricornia for her interjection. She has just said again that the government's policy will do it. Here is the evidence from a report given to the government's own Department of Industrial Relations which says that it is not happening and the government's approaches will not let it happen. I rest my case. That is the situation that I am criticising.
—Would you table that?

—No, I will not table at this stage but I will give the name of the report: Review of progress in workplace reform in the export meat processing sector, by Fellows, Medlock and Associates. It was done specifically at the request of the Department of Industrial Relations. The government stands condemned out of its own mouth.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion—I have not got longer; I could go on for hours if I were able to—I want to make a couple of points. Reform is not about advantaging just one or two sectors of the industry. It is about much broader issues. It is about allowing the industry to continue to grow; about allowing it to maximise its contribution to our export income; about securing a place for those whose employment in places like Rockhampton, the beef capital of Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Casino is the beef capital of Australia.

—No, Casino is the beef capital of New South Wales. This is about securing employment opportunities and eventually, I hope, better living standards for the people who work in those places for those industries. Because of the failure of the government to address these I intend to move in relation to this:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Main Committee deplores the fact that the Government has implemented only one of the Industry Commission's recommendations for the industry and has ignored the others, including important recommendations relating to industrial relations reform and the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service".
Finally, I say this: we will watch the activities of the Meat Industry Council very closely, because in the end the linchpin of the beef industry in this country is the breeders.

PARA.TAB: It is actually the cattlemen and women of this country who have got the greatest investment in the industry, some billions of dollars. They have the most at stake and they are the key to its future and to the future of everybody involved in it, including those people whose work depends upon the meat industry. As Maurice Binstead keeps pointing out to me in Queensland, the breeder is the base of the whole operation.

If this legislation impacts—inasmuch as it does anything—unreasonably on producers, we will be making quick insistence upon reform to this legislation as far as it goes. But in the interests of the broader industry I say: let us have an election, so that we can get in place a government which will actually do something about securing the future of this vitally important Australian rural industry. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Main Committee deplores the fact that the Government has implemented only one of the Industry Commission's recommendations for the industry and has ignored the others, including important recommendations relating to industrial relations reform and the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service".

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Mr Harry Woods) adjourned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Communications and the Arts: Consultants

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 6 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: Has his Department retained (a) McKerlie Consulting Pty Ltd and (b) Kennedy Scott Furphy to provide consultancy services; if so, in each case, what (a) brief was given to the company and (b) is the cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) My Department has retained the Consultancy services of McKerlie Consulting Pty Ltd.

TAB.TAB: (a) A consultant is required to identify and examine alternative structural, administrative and funding arrangements for the provision, operation and management of radiocommunications transmission facilities used for delivery of national broadcasting services (and a number of community and regional commercial services).

PARA.TAB: (b) My Department has retained the Consultancy services of Kennedy Scott Furphy.

TAB.TAB: (a) The consultant will provide a team of fifteen people with various skills to assist the National Transmission Agency (NTA), during a thirteen-month period, in contracting out the maintenance of its Australia-wide network of broadcasting transmission facilities. The major tasks of this consultancy range from: establishing and managing the project team; confirming NTA strategy for the tender; developing tender evaluation criteria and methodology; preparing contracts; calling and evaluating tenders; and negotiating and awarding contracts.
(b) The total cost is $567,000.00.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 9 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: Was the Australian High Commissioner's residence in Singapore sold; if so, what sum did the Government receive from the sale.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes; S$98 million.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Cooksey Report on defence facilities (a) conclude that there was no compelling case in the present financial circumstances to outlay the high cost associated with moving the School of Artillery from North Head, Sydney, and that it should remain there in the short to medium term and (b) recommend that should the School of Artillery be relocated then Rockhampton was the preferred site.
(2) Is the establishment to be moved; if so, in view of the conclusions of the Cooksey Report, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a)&(b) Yes, the 1987 Review of Australia's Defence Facilities (Cooksey Report) did consider that, in the prevailing financial circumstances, there was no compelling case to outlay the high cost associated with moving the School of Artillery from North Head. It also stated that, in the short to medium term, the school should remain at North Head but the review team would favour Rockhampton as a future long-term site for the school.

(2) The School of Artillery is to relocate to Puckapunyal. Since the Cooksey Report was produced in 1987, there have been a number of significant changes in Defence which now make the relocation of the school a timely, efficient and cost-effective proposal.

The Cooksey Report identified that it was desirable for training establishments to be located in south eastern Australia, but in 1987 Puckapunyal was fully utilised. The implementation of the 1991 Force Structure Review initiatives, in particular the move of units to the north, has altered this situation. This proposal will prevent under-utilisation of facilities and the range at Puckapunyal resulting from the move of units to the north.

Relocation to Puckapunyal will provide the School of Artillery with modern, functional training facilities at less cost than at Townsville or Rockhampton. The school will occupy Robertson Barracks at Puckapunyal which will be vacated by the 1st Armoured Regiment later this year when it moves to Darwin. This proposal will utilise existing facilities and will result in a significant saving, in the order of $20 million, in capital investment costs when compared with establishing the school in Townsville and even greater savings compared to the Rockhampton option.
Any significant delay in refurbishing these facilities may result in degradation of the asset and additional funds being required later to return them to a usable state.

The Cooksey Report also identified that access to suitable field-firing ranges for the use of large-calibre weapons (eg artillery) was the greatest problem for NSW-based units. The relocation will provide the School of Artillery with access to such a range at Puckapunyal.
The School of Artillery will be located where there is existing Defence infrastructure that can readily provide support, unlike Rockhampton.
